nodes.label: Acquire Land
nodes.description: 300-400 acres of contiguous forested land in Southern Maine  -  the permanent physical foundation of New Doggerland. The target parcel combines mature mixed forest with varied terrain, adequate natural water features, and proximity to Southern Maine's population centers without being so accessible as to compromise the sense of arrival and seclusion the resort model depends on. Land is secured under a long-term stewardship lease structured for a minimum 200-year term rather than outright purchase, preserving the landowner's underlying ownership while giving New Doggerland the operational security required to invest at institutional scale. The right landowner understands they are not selling; they are partnering with a governance-locked institution designed to outlast them. Finding the land and the right landowner is the founding act  -  everything else is contingent on it. Target acquisition: 2026.

nodes.label: Porta-Potties
nodes.description: The first physical infrastructure on the land  -  portable sanitation units installed before any human activity begins on site. Maine law and basic safety require sanitation provision before volunteers, contractors, or staff work the property. The $3,000 setup covers delivery and initial service; monthly rental runs approximately $270 per unit, covering scheduled servicing and consumables. Two units minimum for early operations. This node is the literal first unlock: nothing else happens until it is in place. It is also the first named donor opportunity on the skill tree  -  modest, unglamorous, and a useful early test of whether a donor's commitment to the mission runs deeper than their preference for prestige.
nodes.perk: "Sanitation made possible by [Donor Name]" acknowledgment on the public tree for each month sponsored.

nodes.label: Fencing
nodes.description: Boundary and operational fencing installed in phases across the estate as different zones come online. The $35,000 Phase 1 allocation covers the highest-priority enclosures: the sanctuary dog runs (welded wire panel, minimum 6 ft), the founder home yard (timber post and rail, dog-safe infill), and initial livestock perimeters for the goat and donkey facilities. Later phases extend fencing to villa yards ($8,000-$15,000 per yard), the campground perimeter, the public dog park airlocks, and the off-leash trail loop. The perimeter wall program gradually takes over the estate boundary function over 25+ years, but operational fencing within the estate is a permanent, expanding infrastructure thread  -  virtually every node that requires secure containment depends on it. Material selection follows the estate aesthetic: timber post and rail where guest-visible, agricultural wire where functional, wildlife-appropriate specification at the forest boundary.

nodes.label: Temporary Water
nodes.description: Temporary potable water provision bridging land acquisition and permanent well installation. IBC (Intermediate Bulk Container) storage tanks  -  typically 275-gallon food-grade totes  -  are filled by scheduled water delivery truck at approximately $300 per month, supporting the founder home, volunteer staging area, and early animal care operations. The $2,500 setup covers tank procurement and plumbing connections. The system is deliberately minimal: reliable enough to sustain early operations, uncomfortable enough to maintain urgency around funding the permanent well. Two to four IBC tanks in series provide 550-1,100 gallons of buffer storage. The temporary system is retired when the Well and Permanent Water node is funded and operational, typically 6-18 months after land acquisition depending on drilling permitting timelines.
nodes.perk: "Founding Water made possible by [Donor Name]" acknowledgment on the public tree.

nodes.label: Power & Solar
nodes.description: A solar-primary electrical system sized for the founder home, volunteer staging area, and early sanctuary operations. The $120,000 installation covers a 20-30 kW solar array, battery storage bank sufficient for 2-3 days of autonomy at early operational loads, a backup generator interface for extended Maine winter overcast periods, and the distribution panel and wiring to serve the first structures. The system is deliberately oversized relative to Phase 1 demand to provide headroom for the sanctuary core's climate control, lighting, and veterinary equipment when those nodes come online. A grid connection application is filed concurrently as a prudent emergency fallback  -  Maine winters and animal welfare obligations make a backup supply non-negotiable. Monthly costs are minimal at this scale; the Power Upgrade node later scales the system for full institutional operations.
nodes.perk: "Founding Power System made possible by [Donor Name]" (signage at the staging area power hub), plus a permanent donor plaque on the electrical room wall.

nodes.label: Basic Trail Network
nodes.description: 15 miles of hand-cut and machine-assisted forest trails across the estate, graded for three ability levels  -  easy (wide, level, suitable for strollers and older visitors), intermediate (natural surface, moderate terrain), and challenge (rooted, hilly, for confident walkers and trail runners). All trails are dog-friendly and marked with color-coded posts. Trailheads feature printed maps, tick-check stations, and waste bag dispensers. The network forms the connective tissue of the entire estate  -  nearly every outdoor program, activity, and experience depends on it being in place.
nodes.perk: Trail network naming: "Trail Network made possible by [Donor Name]", acknowledgment on all printed and digital trail maps, a named trailhead entry marker at the main access point, and optional named trail segments for secondary donors (discreet carved-post markers consistent with the estate aesthetic).

nodes.label: Access Road
nodes.description: An all-weather access route from the nearest public road to the estate's operational core  -  the physical prerequisite for every delivery, emergency vehicle, contractor, and guest that will ever arrive at New Doggerland. The $35,000 Phase 1 cost covers a compacted gravel base road of approximately 0.25-0.5 miles depending on the chosen parcel's road frontage, with adequate width for delivery trucks and emergency vehicles (minimum 12 ft, target 16 ft), basic drainage culverts, and a defined entry point. Cost is site-dependent and should be re-evaluated once land is acquired  -  a parcel with existing forest road infrastructure could reduce this significantly; one requiring new construction through dense forest could increase it to $80,000-$150,000. The entry point is the first impression of the estate for every visitor, contractor, and donor who arrives  -  the entry marker stone is accordingly the first named donor opportunity with genuine public visibility.
nodes.perk: "Access Road made possible by [Donor Name]" entry marker stone at the start of the road (non-intrusive, consistent with the aesthetic).

nodes.label: Sanctuary Rescue Core
nodes.description: A purpose-built 12-dog rescue and adoption facility forming the operational heart of New Doggerland's charitable mission. The facility includes individual kennel suites sized above industry minimum standards, an indoor/outdoor run system, a low-stress intake area, a quarantine suite, a socialisation and assessment space, a volunteer handling room, and a public adoption viewing area. All spaces are designed to minimise kennel stress  -  sound-dampened walls, natural light, visual barriers between kennels, and enrichment infrastructure built in from day one. Dogs are assessed, rehabilitated where needed, matched with adopters through the staff-led matchmaking program, and transitioned through a structured adoption process. At a 12-dog capacity with average length of stay of 12-25 days, the facility can process approximately 175-350 adoptions per year depending on intake type and rehabilitation needs.
nodes.perk: Facility naming: "Rescue Center made possible by [Donor Name]", permanent donor plaque at the main entrance, named individual kennel suites available for secondary donors, and an invitation to the inaugural intake day  -  the first dog through the door.

nodes.label: Veterinary Facility
nodes.description:
A purpose-built veterinary hospital constructed to the specifications of a partner veterinarian, operated as an independent practice on-site rather than as a salaried ND department. New Doggerland builds and maintains the facility; the partner DVM operates their own practice within it, serving sanctuary and rescue dogs at cost and generating revenue through public clientele  -  resort guests, local pet owners, and regional referrals drawn by the quality of the facility and the unusual setting.
The Phase 1 facility is sized for a single DVM with two to three vet techs: one surgical suite, full diagnostic capability (digital X-ray, ultrasound, in-house bloodwork), a dental suite, pharmacy, treatment rooms, and a recovery kennel wing integrated with the sanctuary. At 1,000 dogs per year at full build, this facility scales to a multi-DVM hospital with three to four surgical suites, CT access, a dedicated ICU, and a specialist rotation  -  but Phase 1 establishes the bones of that institution at a scale that can open and operate immediately.
The DVM this facility is designed to attract is leaving corporate veterinary medicine  -  the consolidation, the moral injury of profit-driven care, the loss of autonomy. New Doggerland offers the opposite: a world-class facility in a forest, a rescue mission worth serving, a public practice that is financially sustainable, and complete professional autonomy. In exchange, rescue dogs receive the best available care at cost. This is not a compromise for either party.
The facility is a named donor opportunity of the highest tier. It is also, practically, the infrastructure that makes 1,000 dogs per year possible  -  without it, ND is a shelter. With it, ND is a rescue institution.
nodes.perk: Facility naming: "Veterinary Hospital made possible by [Donor Name]", permanent donor plaque at the hospital entrance, and an invitation to be present at the first surgery performed in the facility.

nodes.label: FluentPet Program
nodes.description: Every dog in New Doggerland's sanctuary receives training on a standardised 24-button communication board before adoption, using a consistent vocabulary and layout across all environments  -  sanctuary, villas, public spaces, and the adopter's home. The board travels with the dog. Adoption fees include the board at no additional cost to the adopter. The 24-button standard vocabulary covers needs (outside, water, food, play, walk, potty, rest, help), emotions (happy, sad, scared, want, love, no), social context (parent figures, friend, stranger, alone, together), and locations (inside, outside, go, home). Expansion boards are available in standardised sets of 12, up to a maximum of 48 buttons across three boards  -  same buttons, same layout as the standard board, ensuring consistency as vocabulary grows. Boards are installed throughout the estate  -  in every villa, at key public locations including the dog park, trail entrances, and Aqua Fetch Bay  -  so dogs can communicate in any environment they encounter during their stay or after adoption. A dog that has learned this vocabulary at New Doggerland will find the same board in their adopted home, in any ND villa, and at any ND public point. The program includes a formal research partnership commitment with FluentPet and academic partners in dog cognition research. New Doggerland's throughput  -  hundreds of dogs per year trained on a standardised board in a controlled environment  -  creates a longitudinal dataset of significant research value. This partnership may offset board costs through sponsorship. This commitment may not be eliminated for cost-saving purposes.
nodes.perk: Program naming: "Communication Program made possible by [Donor Name]", acknowledgment on all board packaging and the program page, and a FluentPet-partnered "Founding Voice" recognition for the primary sponsor.

nodes.label: Outdoor Dog Daycare
nodes.description: Outdoor dog daycare operation for up to 50 dogs, divided into 4 fenced play areas, staffed to supervision ratio guidance, with water provision, shade or shelter, waste stations, basic tick-control points, making use of trails and facilities, and controlled entry and exit handling.
nodes.perk: Daycare naming: "Dog Daycare made possible by [Donor Name]", named yards (four area plaques), named water stations, named shade or shelter structure, and a sponsor plaque at the entry control point.

nodes.label: Dog Matchmaking Walks
nodes.description:
Guests without dogs  -  or guests who want company on the trail  -  request a matched walk through the sanctuary team. Staff assess the guest's energy, pace, experience with dogs, and personality before selecting a specific sanctuary dog for them. The match is deliberate, not random. They walk together for 1-2 hours on the trail network with no adoption pressure and no sales pitch. Just a walk.
The match is logged. Returning guests are reunited with the same dog on subsequent visits. Relationships develop across multiple stays. Some end in adoption  -  the guest has already spent hours with this dog in a forest, in all weathers, at their own pace. That is not a purchase. That is a decision made from knowledge. All matchmaking walks are valuable regardless of whether adoption follows.
For sanctuary dogs, the program provides structured human socialisation, trail time, and the kind of calm one-to-one attention that kennel life cannot replicate. A dog that has walked regularly with guests is a more accurately assessed, more adoptable dog.
The program is also available to guests who simply want canine company on the trail and have no interest in adoption. No qualification required.
nodes.perk: Program naming: "Matchmaking Walks Program made possible by [Donor Name]", acknowledgment on the program page and trail signage, and an invitation to walk with the first matched pair on launch day.

nodes.label: Scent Coding System
nodes.description:
An estate-wide scent architecture designed around the primary sense of the dog, applied consistently across four domains.
Villas. Each villa carries a unique, subtle scent signature delivered via a low-level diffuser using natural essential oil blends. A dog that stays in Villa 7 learns within hours that this specific scent means home base  -  safety, their humans, their bed. The scent persists at low concentration throughout the stay, reducing anxiety particularly for rescue dogs and dogs in unfamiliar environments. Returning guests can request the same scent profile on subsequent stays, allowing a dog to re-orient immediately upon arrival.
Staff uniforms. Each department carries a distinct scent worked into a collar or wristband worn by all staff in that role  -  light enough to be imperceptible to most humans, unambiguous to a dog. Veterinary and medical staff carry one signature; kennel and animal care staff another; guest-facing and hospitality staff a third; sanctuary behavior staff a fourth. A dog smells an approaching staff member and has a moment of preparation before the interaction begins  -  the vet tech scent triggers mild alert, the play coordinator scent triggers anticipation, the foster carer scent triggers calm. Dogs read intent before body language even begins.
Trails. Scent markers at trail junctions and decision points  -  subtle posts at dog nose height  -  provide directional and territorial information in the dog's own language. Safe zones carry one scent family; caution or boundary areas carry another. A dog moving through the trail network reads their environment continuously rather than navigating it blind.
Boundaries. The perimeter of safe off-leash zones is scent-marked as well as physically fenced, providing a redundant sensory boundary that dogs register instinctively. This is particularly valuable for sanctuary dogs being introduced to off-leash freedom for the first time  -  the scent boundary communicates "this is the edge" in a language more immediate than a fence line.
The system requires formulation of consistent, species-appropriate scent blends, staff training in application and maintenance, and a refresh protocol to maintain concentration levels year-round.
nodes.perk: System naming: "Scent Environment made possible by [Donor Name]", acknowledgment on the system's interpretive signage, and an invitation to work with the scent formulation team on the villa signature series.

nodes.label: Dog Scent Menu
nodes.description: A purpose-built interactive scent station installed in the restaurant, allowing dogs to express a meal preference before food is prepared. The $8,000 covers fabrication of the station  -  a low, angled panel at dog nose height with sealed scent cartridges corresponding to each available protein and carbohydrate option on the dog menu. A dog that lingers at the salmon cartridge is indicating salmon; one that returns repeatedly to chicken is telling its owner something worth acting on. Staff record the preference and prepare accordingly. The system is deliberately low-tech: no electronics, no data capture. Just a dog being consulted about its meal in the language available to it. For guests, watching their dog make a deliberate food choice is one of the more quietly remarkable moments the estate offers. The scent menu also feeds into the Kustom Kibble consultation process  -  a dog's demonstrated preferences in the restaurant inform the Koncierge's blend recommendation in the store. Scent cartridges are replaced monthly at minimal ongoing cost.

nodes.label: On-Site Animal Adoption
nodes.description:
A zoo-style animal sponsorship program allowing visitors, resort guests, and remote supporters to sponsor a specific named animal in New Doggerland's care. Sponsors pay the full annual cost footprint of their animal  -  covering food, veterinary care, enrichment, and housing  -  on an annual renewable contract. Available across all sanctuary species: dogs, donkeys, goats, and ducks.
Sponsors receive a named plaque on their animal's stall or pen, monthly photo and video updates, unlimited scheduled visits, participation in supervised care activities (grooming, feeding, walking), and immediate notification if their animal requires significant medical attention. Sponsors may provide input on enrichment and, where an animal is unnamed at the time of sponsorship, naming rights. New Doggerland retains full care authority in all circumstances  -  animal welfare supersedes sponsor preferences.
The program is designed to serve people who love animals but cannot keep them: elderly visitors who want a specific animal to visit regularly, families with rental restrictions or allergies, urban supporters who want a genuine ongoing connection, and children learning responsibility without the full commitment of ownership. A sponsored donkey or rescue dog is also an unusually good gift. Sponsorship does not confer ownership or adoption rights. Animals that are adopted out of the sanctuary are retired from the program with a closing update to their sponsor.
This program may not be eliminated for cost-saving purposes.
nodes.perk: Program naming: "Animal Sponsorship Program made possible by [Donor Name]", acknowledgment on all sponsorship materials and the program page, and a reserved sponsorship of the first animal enrolled in each species category.

nodes.label: Master Waller Dwelling
nodes.description:
The master waller's permanent residence, built by the waller themselves in their first season on the estate using the same drystone craft they will practice for the remainder of their career at New Doggerland. The waller designs and leads the build, hiring a seasonal laborer for stone lifting and supply, a timber framer for the roof structure, and licensed trades for plumbing and electrical. New Doggerland provides materials, groundwork preparation, and equipment. The waller provides the skill, the design, and the hands.
The dwelling is integrated into or directly adjacent to the perimeter wall  -  the waller's own first major work on the estate, and a permanent demonstration of what the wall program will become. It is built to last as long as the wall itself.
The dwelling is the waller's home for life. Lifetime residence rights are protected in the governance documents  -  the waller cannot be displaced except by their own choice. It is not a staff house. It is their house, built by them, in stone, on this land. The position is a lifetime appointment with full creative and technical autonomy over wall design, technique, and material selection. The waller is expected to train apprentices over time  -  potentially including foster youth alumni  -  ensuring the craft and the wall continue beyond any single person's working life.
The right person for this role values craft over income, thinks in decades rather than years, and wants a life's work rather than a contract. Finding them is one of the most important early tasks of the organization.
nodes.perk: Dwelling naming: "Waller's Cottage made possible by [Donor Name]", permanent donor plaque on the exterior stone, and an invitation to be present when the first course of stone is laid.

nodes.label: Perimeter Wall (Begin)
nodes.description: The beginning of New Doggerland's most ambitious long-horizon infrastructure project: a dry-stone perimeter wall enclosing the estate boundary, built by a resident master waller over an estimated 25-year construction period. The $120,000 Phase 1 node funds the first season of active wall construction  -  stone sourced on-site from field clearing and trail work, supplemented by purchased dressed stone where needed, plus the master waller's first-year compensation ($55,000-$85,000 depending on experience and arrangement) and groundwork preparation for the first wall sections. A dry-stone wall of this scale  -  3+ miles of perimeter  -  is not built in one phase or one decade. It is a generational project, funded in stages through the Hero Stones Program, estate operations, and designated capital gifts. The $8,000 monthly covers ongoing waller compensation and materials once construction is active. The wall serves simultaneously as boundary infrastructure, ecological habitat (dry-stone walls are among the most biodiverse built structures in temperate landscapes), aesthetic identity, and institutional statement. A 25-year construction project signals, more convincingly than any document, that New Doggerland intends to be here in 200 years.
nodes.perk: Wall naming: "Perimeter Wall made possible by [Donor Name]"; named wall segments and individual stones (including Hero Stones); plaque at the wall's primary public-facing entry point.

nodes.label: Hero Stones Programme
nodes.description: A permanent, multi-tier donor recognition program integrated into the fabric of the perimeter wall itself. Donors purchase the right to have a stone carved and set into the wall at a position corresponding to their tier  -  from standard community stones through to ultra-premium auctioned keystones at the main gate arch. All inscriptions are donor-chosen within approved guidelines, carved by the master waller or a commissioned stone carver, and permanent. The program runs for the full 25-year construction life of the wall, creating a perpetual fundraising mechanism that funds 40-60% of wall construction costs as it proceeds. The wall is never "finished" as a fundraising vehicle  -  new sections mean new stones, new placement ceremonies, and new donor engagement year after year. Stone tiers:Legendary (auction only)  -  Main gate arch keystone (one only), entry gate pillars (pair), corner foundation stones (×4). Auctioned at the annual Stone Ceremony Gala. Opening bids from $50,000; expected $75,000-$150,000 for the keystone. Placement is a private ceremony for the donor and up to 20 guests, with the master waller setting the stone by hand. Premium  -  Section markers, archway keystones, gateway thresholds, coping stones. $1,500-$7,500. Donors receive a site visit during carving, a placement ceremony invitation, professional photography, a framed rubbing of their inscription, and GPS coordinates for their stone. Community  -  Standard wall stones and memorial benches. $250-$3,500. Donors receive online inscription preview, stone number and section assignment, email updates as their stone approaches placement, and an open invitation to quarterly Wall Progress Days. Foster youth stones  -  Earned, not purchased, by program graduates. Placed alongside donor stones with no visible distinction. A placement ceremony is held quarterly; graduates learn basic walling technique from the master waller before setting their own stone. The wall makes no hierarchy between a $100,000 keystone donor and a youth who found their footing here. Both names are carved in the same stone. Inscription guidelines: Personal dedications, memorial messages, family markers, and mission-aligned statements are welcome. Commercial messaging, political statements, and hateful content are prohibited. All inscriptions are reviewed and approved before carving. Donors may revise or withdraw rather than be declined.
nodes.perk: Program naming: "Hero Stones Program made possible by [Donor Name]", acknowledgment on all program materials and the wall's permanent interpretive signage, and a reserved Legendary tier stone in the first auction.

nodes.label: Memorial Urn Stones
nodes.description:
A tiered memorial program integrated into the perimeter wall, allowing guests, members, workers, volunteers, adopters, and alumni to permanently commemorate a beloved animal within the fabric of the estate.
Tier 1  -  Memorial Stone: An inscribed dressed stone set into a prominent section of the perimeter wall, bearing the animal's name, species, and dates. Carved by the master waller or a commissioned stone carver in a style consistent with the wall's aesthetic. No ashes interred. Available for any species.
Tier 2  -  Urn Stone: A purpose-prepared wall section with a sealed hollow chamber behind a carved face stone, allowing cremated remains to be permanently interred within the wall itself. The face stone bears the animal's name, species, dates, and an optional short inscription. Chamber is sealed with lime mortar consistent with the wall construction. Subject to applicable Maine law governing interment of animal remains  -  legal review completed before program launch. Available for any species, subject to chamber sizing constraints.
Both tiers are permanent. The wall is built to last centuries. An annual memorial gathering is held at the wall each autumn for families of interred and commemorated animals.
nodes.perk: Program naming: "Memorial Program made possible by [Donor Name]", acknowledgment on all program materials, and a complimentary Tier 1 memorial stone for the program's founding sponsor's own animal.

nodes.label: Dutch Snackbar
nodes.description: A permanent food service unit - static food truck or purpose-built kiosk - operating in or adjacent to the central village, serving wood-fired pizza and a curated menu of Dutch street food on Friday through Sunday afternoons and evenings. The Dutch menu reflects the Founder's cultural heritage and is treated as a genuine culinary offering: kapsalon (fries topped with döner meat, melted Gouda, and garlic sauce), patat speciaal (fries with mayo, curry ketchup, and raw onion), patat oorlog (fries with peanut sauce and mayo). Wood-fired pizza uses estate-grown toppings where seasonal availability allows. The $35,000 covers the vehicle or kiosk structure, pizza oven installation, and initial fitout. Operating three days per week at 50-80 covers per service, the snackbar generates $40,000-$220,000 annually depending on season and villa occupancy. It is also the Dutch cultural thread made edible - one of several ways the estate's founding identity is woven into daily operations without being announced.

nodes.label: Forest Dining
nodes.description:
Distributed forest dining across 20 grill sites dispersed through the estate - each consisting of a well-drained concrete pad, a simple wooden roof, a gas patio heater, a permanent gas grill, and a laminated menu with a two-way radio post. Guests book a site in advance and order a grill pack from the menu. A staff member arrives by golf cart, unfurls a white tablecloth on the picnic table, sets out proper plates, silverware, and grill tools, lights the grill, and disappears back into the trees. When the guests radio that they're done, staff returns to clear everything. No commercial kitchen. No restaurant building. No waiting staff hovering. Just private forest, a proper grill, and someone who has thought of everything.
Summer packs range from a Classic (burgers, corn, potato salad) to a Premium (ribeye, lobster tail, compound butter). A Dutch pack features bratwurst. Winter operation switches to fondue - cheese, broth, or chocolate - delivered and set up at the same sites with patio heaters running. Pizza and fried snacks from the Dutch Snackbar are deliverable to grill sites via the same golf cart infrastructure. When villas are operational, the identical service extends to villa decks.
No income in the construction period. Sites become operational as soon as the concrete pads and roof structures are complete - potentially within months of land acquisition, ahead of most other revenue nodes.
nodes.perk: Program naming: "Forest Dining Program made possible by [Donor Name]", acknowledgment on all menus and the booking system, a named grill site with a discreet carved post marker, and an invitation to the inaugural white-tablecloth dinner in the forest.

nodes.label: The Long Table
nodes.description:
A purpose-built long table  -  permanent, beautiful, weather-protected  -  hosted by the Founder Steward on a monthly basis in the early phases, moving to weekly as the estate matures. Seating is fixed at twelve to sixteen. The guest list is deliberately mixed across every stratum of the estate's life: major donors and first-year volunteers, artisan partners and board members, visiting legislators and sanctuary staff, a foster youth alumnus and a construction foreman. The only criterion is that everyone at the table has some genuine stake in what New Doggerland is becoming.
The meal is family-style  -  dishes passed, not plated. The menu is whatever the estate's own kitchen, baker, forager, and garden have produced that week. Nothing is imported for the occasion. The table eats what the land and its people made.
No phones. A small wooden box sits beside each place. The ask is simple and non-negotiable.
One ritual: each person at the table serves the person to their right  -  passes dishes, pours drinks, clears plates. Not staff. Not a gesture. The actual service of the meal, performed by everyone simultaneously, for the duration. A major donor fills a kennel worker's glass. The Founder Steward clears someone else's plate. Nobody is the host. Nobody is the guest. Twelve people take care of each other for three hours.
Dogs are welcome under the table.
The Long Table is not a networking event. It is not a cultivation dinner. It is not a thank-you. It is the Founder Steward's weekly practice of the belief that the institution is built by people who know each other as people  -  and that knowing each other as people requires sitting together and sharing food, not exchanging business cards.
nodes.perk: Table naming: "The Long Table made possible by [Donor Name]", permanent donor plaque on the table itself  -  inlaid, flush with the surface, carved by the estate's woodworker  -  and a standing invitation to one seat at every Long Table dinner for the duration of the donor's relationship with the estate.

nodes.label: Gingerworks
nodes.description: New Doggerland's on-site micro-brewery and taproom  -  the Founder's retirement project, operational once the resort has reached sufficient scale to sustain it. Gingerworks specialises in alcoholic ginger beers brewed on-site using ginger and chaga cultivated on the estate, producing a genuinely estate-grown product from soil to glass. The $350,000 covers brewery fitout including fermentation vessels, conditioning tanks, a small bottling and canning line, taproom furniture and bar infrastructure, and cold storage. The taproom is a resort amenity  -  open to villa guests and estate staff, not the general public  -  but Gingerworks product is available for retail purchase through the estate gift shop and any other public-facing retail channel, allowing visitors and day guests who never enter the taproom to take a bottle home. The flagship product is a chaga ginger beer: warming, complex, and genuinely rooted in this specific piece of Maine forest. Seasonal and experimental variants rotate through the taproom on draft. The brewery's small scale  -  nano to micro range  -  is deliberate: quality and story over volume. Gingerworks is not a commercial brewery that happens to be on the estate. It is the Founder's long-horizon personal project, built into the institution's fabric from the beginning, and its products are the most literal expression of the estate's crop-to-glass ambitions.

nodes.label: Repair Culture
nodes.description:
A large open-sided maker space in the central village  -  permanently staffed, permanently visible, permanently active. Stations for textiles, leather, woodwork, metalwork, electronics, ceramics, and whatever else arrives that someone wants to extend the life of. Staffed primarily by retired craftspeople, local teachers, and skilled hobbyists on flexible arrangements  -  volunteers, modest stipends, or in-kind arrangements with the estate. Foster youth apprentices rotate through. Agricultural college students complete placements here. The artisan partners contribute where their craft overlaps.
The guiding principle is the kintsugi ethic applied without limit: repair is not concealment, it is transformation. Every repair is made deliberately visible. Contrast thread on fabric. A different wood species filling a crack. Decorative metal staples through a ceramic break. An embroidered patch that draws the eye. The object leaves more interesting than it arrived  -  carrying the record of its damage as part of its identity rather than hiding it. Guests watch repairs happen. Many participate. Some bring items specifically to have them repaired this way.
The workshop serves four functions simultaneously. It is a paid guest service  -  modest fees for repairs completed while guests stay. It is an ND overhead reduction tool  -  all estate equipment, furniture, uniforms, and tools are repaired here before replacement, potentially saving $20,000-$50,000 per year in asset replacement costs. It is an apprenticeship and skills pipeline, particularly for foster youth aging out of care who leave with a marketable, transferable craft skill. And it is a cultural statement  -  a working demonstration that repair is worth celebrating, that objects have lives worth extending, and that the skills to extend them are worth preserving.
The space is open-sided by design. It is meant to be seen, heard, and smelled from the central village. The sound of a hammer, the smell of leather and wood, the sight of an elderly craftsperson teaching a teenager to stitch  -  these are not background details. They are the point.
nodes.perk: Workshop naming: "Repair Workshop made possible by [Donor Name]", permanent donor plaque at the workshop entrance, and a commissioned piece  -  an object of the donor's choosing, repaired or transformed by the workshop's craftspeople in the visible-mend tradition, presented as a gift.

nodes.label: Unitarian Chapel
nodes.description: A small timber-frame chapel and Garden of Remembrance serving the full estate community and the general public  -  open to everyone regardless of background, belief, or affiliation. The $225,000 covers the chapel structure (30-50 person capacity), adjacent Garden of Remembrance with perennial planting, quiet paths, and a columbarium, and the fitout of both spaces to a simple, beautiful standard consistent with the estate aesthetic. The chapel is Unitarian Universalist in tradition  -  meaning it carries no creed, imposes no doctrine, and welcomes all. A resident UU minister is attached to the estate, available for weddings, animal and human funerals, memorial services, and private reflection. There are no sermons. The minister's role is to hold space, officiate ceremonies, and be present  -  not to instruct. The chapel is available for hire by outside parties for weddings and funerals, making it one of the estate's few genuinely public-facing buildings. Animals are welcome. Ceremonies for the death of a beloved dog are conducted here with the same care and seriousness as any other service. The Garden of Remembrance connects directly to the Memorial Urn Stones program in the perimeter wall  -  families who choose to inter ashes in the wall may begin and end that process in the garden. The Founder may be interred in the garden, marked with a simple stone of no greater prominence than any other.

nodes.label: Extreme Fetch Field
nodes.description:
A fan-shaped outfield designed specifically for high-intensity dog fetch, equipped with three tiered mechanical launch systems firing at short (30m), medium (60m), and long (90m+) distances. The field is fenced to contain dogs and retrieve objects, with a handler's platform at the apex of the fan where guests operate the launchers. The layout allows multiple dogs to fetch simultaneously on diverging lines without collision. The field is sited on marginal land  -  the fan shape works naturally on a cleared hillside or open edge zone that would otherwise serve no purpose  -  turning terrain that can't support sanctuary or villa use into an active guest amenity.
The three-tier launch system is the feature. A guest who has never thrown a ball 90 metres in their life can watch their dog cover that distance at full speed inside ten seconds. There is nothing else quite like it.
nodes.perk: Field naming: "Extreme Fetch Field made possible by [Donor Name]", sponsor plaque at the handler's platform, and named individual launch tiers for secondary donors.

nodes.label: Aqua Fetch Bay
nodes.description:
A fan-shaped outdoor water area sited at a natural pond edge or constructed bay, designed as the aquatic counterpart to the Extreme Fetch Field. Three tiered launch systems fire retrieve objects into the water at short, medium, and long range  -  the dog enters at the apex of the fan and swims out along the diverging lanes. Non-slip docks and graduated ramps line the handler's platform and the retrieve area. One-dog-at-a-time release controls on the long-range lane prevent collision in the water. Drift capture geometry at the far end of the fan slows and corrals floating retrieve objects so they don't disperse across the full water body.
The experience for the dog is fundamentally different from the dry-land version  -  sustained swimming at full athletic effort, combined with the retrieve drive, produces a quality of physical exhaustion that even very high-energy dogs rarely reach on land. For handlers watching from the platform, a dog covering 60 meters of open water at full speed to reach a floating object and swimming back with it is one of the more purely satisfying things the estate offers.
The outdoor Aqua Fetch Bay operates seasonally in Maine conditions  -  May through October reliably, with weather-dependent extension at both ends. The indoor version within The Jewel provides year-round access once that facility is built.
nodes.perk: Bay naming: "Aqua Fetch Bay made possible by [Donor Name]", sponsor plaque at the handler's platform, and named individual launch tiers for secondary donors.

nodes.label: Natural Ice Rink
nodes.description: A naturally flooded outdoor skating rink occupying a level clearing in the forest, maintained through repeated thin-layer flooding during freezing temperatures. The rink is bordered by packed snow berms, lit for evening skating, and served by a simple skate-change shelter with benches and boot storage. Skate rentals are available on-site. The rink connects directly to the forest skating trail network once that node is active, making it the hub of winter ice activity on the estate. Operational only when temperatures reliably sustain natural ice  -  typically December through February in Southern Maine, weather permitting.
nodes.perk: Rink naming: "Ice Rink made possible by [Donor Name]", sponsor plaque at the skate shelter, and an invitation to the inaugural first-ice ceremony.

nodes.label: Forest Skating Trails
nodes.description:
A network of flooded, frozen skating trails routed through the forest in the Montreal style  -  trails 6-8 feet wide, wide enough for two skaters to pass, carved through the trees and maintained by a small used zamboni that runs the circuit weekly. The surface is prepared on the existing compacted trail base, flooded in thin layers during sustained freezing temperatures. Season runs December through February in Southern Maine, weather permitting.
The trails connect to and extend from the natural ice rink, which serves as the hub  -  the rink for skills, hockey, and open skating; the forest trails for the experience. The two function as a single winter ice program.
The signature offering is the evening session. When the RFID system is active, skaters move through their own personal sphere of light and sound  -  uplighting rising in the trees ahead, music shifting as they glide between them, breath visible in the cold air. This experience does not exist elsewhere in the United States. Montrealers know it. Americans have not seen it. The first time a guest skates through an uplighted Maine forest at night, they will tell everyone they know.
Pricing reflects this: day skating $20/person, evening RFID session $35/person, skate rental $12. Chaga tea included in evening sessions. Family day pass $65. Local community season pass $150.
nodes.perk: Trail network naming: "Forest Skating Trails made possible by [Donor Name]", sponsor acknowledgment at the trailhead and on the skating map, and an invitation to the inaugural first-night session.

nodes.label: Tunnel Network
nodes.description:
A network of buried passage tunnels connecting the primary dog zones across the estate, designed specifically for dogs but sized to allow an adult human to enter on hands and knees for maintenance, retrieval, or the occasional shared adventure. Tunnels are constructed from durable HDPE or fiberglass culvert with proper drainage, ventilation, and smooth interior surfaces. The network includes ground-level observation domes at regular intervals  -  clear acrylic hemispheres flush with the ground surface  -  allowing visitors above to watch dogs moving through the system below, and dogs to look up at the world from underground. Periodic underground chambers provide rest, turning, and social interaction space between tunnel runs.
The system connects the sanctuary exercise areas, the resort dog zones, and the trail-adjacent off-leash areas, allowing dogs to move freely between zones without gate handling. For dogs, it is infrastructure. For guests watching a dog disappear into the ground, reappear at a dome thirty metres away, and vanish again, it is theatre.
nodes.perk: Network naming: "Tunnel Network made possible by [Donor Name]", sponsor acknowledgment at the main tunnel entry portal, and named individual observation domes available for secondary donors  -  a discreet circular plaque flush with the ground surface around the dome rim.

nodes.label: Mood Meadow
nodes.description:
A planted meadow area divided into loosely defined zones, each seeded and maintained with plants selected for their effect on canine neurology and behavior  -  attractive, interesting, or mildly psychoactive to dogs through scent, taste, or contact. Dogs move through the meadow freely and self-select: which zone to roll in, graze, rest in, or return to. No intervention from handlers. The choice is the dog's.
Planting palette includes valerian (calming, mildly sedating), chamomile (soothing), lavender (relaxing), mint (stimulating, alerting), catnip (psychoactive in dogs at low doses  -  excitement and play behavior), wild strawberry (scent interest, mild excitement), lemon balm (calming), and meadowsweet. All species are selected for safety at normal self-regulated doses  -  the meadow is not a pharmaceutical intervention but an enriched environment that formalizes what dogs already do instinctively when given access to varied plant life.
Interpretive signage explains the zones and their intended effects to visiting humans, who frequently find the meadow as interesting to observe as the dogs find it to inhabit. A dog that gravitates consistently to the valerian section tells its owner something useful. One that bypasses the calm zones entirely and returns repeatedly to catnip tells them something else. The meadow generates observational data on canine botanical self-medication  -  a largely unstudied area with genuine research value.
The meadow requires minimal ongoing maintenance: seasonal replanting of annual species, occasional mowing of paths between zones, and monitoring for invasive encroachment.
nodes.perk: Meadow naming: "Mood Meadow made possible by [Donor Name]", sponsor plaque at the meadow entry, and named individual planting zones for secondary donors.

nodes.label: Mechanical Sound Pads
nodes.description: A series of pressure-actuated mechanical pads set flush with the ground along a dedicated trail or play area, scattered at irregular intervals and unpredictable positions. Each pad is constructed from a different material combination  -  tuned hardwood blocks, metal resonators, stone on stone, stretched hide over a wooden frame  -  so that stepping or pouncing on each produces a distinct resonant sound: a deep BONK, a bright DING, a hollow CLONK, a soft THUMP. No electronics. No power. No moving parts beyond the mechanism itself. Pure physics. The pads are made on-site by the estate's resident craftspeople  -  blacksmith and woodworker in collaboration  -  tuned by hand and set into the ground as permanent trail features. Each is weatherproof by nature of its construction, maintenance-free, and effectively indestructible under normal use. Dogs discover the pads by accident. A paw lands on one and something happens. The dog stops. Looks. Steps again. The sound repeats. This is not a toy that a human controls  -  it is an environment that responds to the dog's own movement. The cause-and-effect discovery, the repeatability, the unpredictability of which pad makes which sound  -  these are the enrichment. Some dogs work methodically through the trail. Some return to a favorite pad repeatedly. Some ignore them entirely. All of it is useful to observe. For visiting guests, watching a dog discover the trail for the first time is an experience in itself.
nodes.perk: Trail naming: "Sound Trail made possible by [Donor Name]", sponsor plaque at the trail entry, and the option to commission a named pad  -  a specific tone, a specific material, made by the estate's craftspeople, with a small flush marker.

nodes.label: Central Village
nodes.description: The permanent civic and commercial heart of the estate  -  a compact, walkable cluster of interconnected buildings forming the arrival point, operational hub, and social center of New Doggerland. The $800,000 node funds the core village structure: reception and guest services, the primary restaurant, the Kustom Kibble storefront, staff offices and welfare areas, public toilet facilities, the Long Table dining shelter, and covered circulation connecting all components. The village is designed to the winning specification from the Central Village Design Contest  -  dog-forward throughout, natural materials, year-round operability in Maine's climate, and a spatial logic that makes arrival feel discovered rather than managed. Guests move from the parking lot through a brief forest corridor before the village opens ahead of them. The central village does not open until Phase 3, when villa occupancy justifies full-time food and beverage operations  -  but its construction is the prerequisite for the restaurant, Kustom Kibble, the Long Table, artisan retail, and the guest services infrastructure that a 150-villa resort requires.

nodes.label: First 10 Villas
nodes.description:
The first ten villas on the estate, establishing the BOGO model in its most visible form. Every paying guest at the standard rate of $1,300 per night funds a free stay for someone who needs it  -  a DV survivor, a foster family, a veteran, a low-income family who has never had access to a forest resort. The two stays are indistinguishable. Same villa, same service, same forest dining, same matchmaking walks, same everything. The mission guest does not know which stay was paid and which was funded. Neither does anyone else.
The villas are built to the winning specification from the Villa Design Contest  -  dog-forward spatial design throughout, natural materials, full Maine thermal performance, integrated with the forest rather than cleared from it. Each includes an exclusive-use outdoor yard of at least 5,445 sq ft (1/8 acre), fully fenced, child and dog safe, with the target of 10,890 sq ft (1/4 acre) where site conditions allow. All villas are structurally identical regardless of location. Location determines quality ranking, not construction standard.
The first villa built is the founder's  -  the worst-location unit on the estate, furthest from amenities, least favorable views, built first while site conditions are roughest. Emergency staff housing occupies the next-worst locations. Paying guests and mission guests occupy the best. This hierarchy is encoded in the governance documents and cannot be reversed.
At ten villas, the resort is not yet financially self-sustaining  -  this is a proof-of-concept phase, generating early revenue, testing operations, and demonstrating the model to the major donors who will fund the next twenty.
nodes.perk: Cohort naming: "First Ten Villas made possible by [Donor Name]", permanent acknowledgment on the estate's founding donor wall in the central village, and the option to name one individual villa for a secondary donor.

nodes.label: Next 20 Villas
nodes.description: Expansion from the first ten villas to thirty, scaling the resort to the threshold of financial sustainability and proving the BOGO model at meaningful volume. The $5,000,000 covers construction of twenty additional villas to the same specification as the first cohort  -  same build standard, same minimum yard sizes, same materials  -  with location quality distributed according to the governance hierarchy: best-located units allocated to paying and mission guests, not to staff or operational use. At thirty villas, the resort begins generating the operating surplus that funds sanctuary operations at scale, reduces dependence on donor capital for running costs, and provides the financial track record that unlocks the major institutional funding required for Phase 4. The next twenty villas are also the first cohort built with the full operational infrastructure  -  central village, permanent water, paved road, full trail network  -  in place from day one, meaning the guest experience is materially better than the first ten. Each villa in this cohort is a named donor opportunity in its own right.

nodes.label: 50+ Villas
nodes.description: Expansion from thirty villas to fifty-plus, completing the resort's primary accommodation inventory and establishing the full BOGO model at operational scale. The $10,000,000 covers construction of twenty or more additional villas, artisan housing (built to the same villa specification, grouped in a dedicated cluster away from guest areas), and any remaining estate infrastructure required to support full-capacity operations. At fifty-plus villas, the resort is generating the revenue that makes The Jewel fundable, the transport fleet viable, and the sanctuary's 1,000-dogs-per-year ambition achievable. Artisan partners housed on-site at this phase have the residential stability that makes long-term craft commitments possible  -  the bootmaker, the waller's apprentice, the blacksmith are no longer commuting. This phase also marks the point at which New Doggerland transitions from a project being built into an institution that exists. The governance framework, the physical estate, the operational model, and the community are all present simultaneously for the first time.

nodes.label: Kustom Kibble
nodes.description:
A flagship retail experience occupying a dedicated storefront in the central village  -  the Jelly Belly factory store model applied to premium dog nutrition. Twenty to forty vertical dispensers line the walls in clear tubes, displaying bulk ingredients by category: proteins (chicken, beef, lamb, salmon, duck, venison), grains (rice, oats, quinoa, barley), vegetables (sweet potato, peas, carrots, pumpkin), supplements (glucosamine, fish oil, probiotics, joint support), and treat additions (freeze-dried liver, salmon bits). The store is visually compelling, educational, and interactive. Guests arrive with a dog and leave with a custom blend formulated for that specific animal.
The Kibble Koncierge  -  trained in canine nutrition, not just retail  -  guides each consultation. Age, weight, activity level, health conditions, allergies, current diet, and the dog's own demonstrated preferences via the scent menu all inform the recommendation. The Koncierge specifies a blend by percentage across components, the dispenser measures precisely, and the dog samples a bowl on-site before the guest commits to a purchase. The sample is free. The sample is also the most effective sales tool in the store  -  a dog that visibly loves what it's eating converts its owner immediately.
Every pound purchased funds a pound donated to a New Doggerland adopter who cannot afford quality nutrition for the dog they just took home. The effective cost to the guest is $8 per pound. The effective cost per dog fed  -  across the paying guest's dog and the donated pound  -  is $4. This undercuts premium commercial kibble while delivering a formulation specifically suited to the individual animal. The BOGO model cannot be eliminated for cost-saving purposes.
Alumni adopters receive an ongoing subsidy  -  part of ND's lifelong dog support commitment  -  ensuring that the quality of nutrition a dog received in the sanctuary does not drop the moment it leaves. Online reordering is available to all guests and alumni, extending the revenue stream well beyond the on-site visit.
nodes.perk: Store naming: "Kustom Kibble made possible by [Donor Name]", permanent donor plaque at the store entrance, and the option to name the Kibble Koncierge program  -  the trained staff role that makes the experience possible.

nodes.label: Artisan Housing
nodes.description: A dedicated residential cluster for artisan partners  -  built to the same specification as guest villas, with the same construction standard, the same minimum outdoor yard area, and the same material quality, but grouped together in a distinct area of the estate away from guest accommodation zones. The $1,500,000 covers 6-10 dwellings sized for individuals or couples, with yards appropriately fenced for dogs. Artisan partners who occupy these dwellings have made long-term commitments to the estate  -  the master waller, the bootmaker, the blacksmith, the woodworker, the herbalist  -  and their housing reflects the seriousness of that commitment. This is not staff housing. It is not transient accommodation. It is a small, permanent residential community within the estate, occupied by people whose craft is embedded in New Doggerland's identity. Tenure arrangements are formalised in individual artisan partnership agreements, with governance protections ensuring that partners cannot be displaced without cause. The cluster is designed for neighborliness: close enough that artisans know each other, far enough from guest villas that both communities have genuine privacy.

nodes.label: Memory Lane Trail
nodes.description: A 2-3 mile contemplative trail through the quietest section of the estate's forest, equipped with a weatherproof synchronised speaker system delivering a curated listening experience at low volume throughout the walk. The $28,000 covers weatherproof ground-level speaker units spaced every 40-60 metres along the trail, a central playback system, and the initial audio curation. The playlist spans 1955-2016  -  six decades of popular music sequenced to move through time as the walker moves through the forest. A guest who enters the trail in 1955 and walks for ninety minutes exits near 2016. The experience is solo by design  -  bookable for single walkers and small groups, not open to general foot traffic during active sessions. Dogs are welcome throughout. There is no signage explaining what the trail is. A guest learns about it from staff, from their villa information pack, or from another guest who walked it and cannot quite articulate what it did to them. It is one of the hardest things on the estate to describe and one of the most frequently mentioned in guest feedback.

nodes.label: RFID Light & Sound
nodes.description: A personalised light and sound system that creates a moving environmental response around each guest as they move through specific trail and outdoor zones at night. The $120,000 covers RFID reader infrastructure along the forest skating trails and key nocturnal trail sections, passive RFID tags embedded in guest wristbands issued at check-in, and a control system that triggers uplighting in the trees ahead of an approaching guest  -  warm amber uplights rising in sequence 30-50 metres forward of their position  -  while shifting the ambient soundscape through low-volume forest speakers. Each guest moves through their own private envelope of light and sound. Two guests passing on the trail experience briefly overlapping spheres before each resolves back to its own. The system was conceived for the forest skating trails  -  a guest skating through an uplighted Maine forest at night is one of the estate's signature experiences, not currently available anywhere else in the United States  -  but extends to evening trail walking, the Memory Lane Trail, and any night-time outdoor programming where the effect enhances rather than intrudes. The RFID wristband doubles as the estate's access and payment system for all bookable activities.

nodes.label: Water Channels
nodes.description:
A network of stone-lined water channels and rills distributed through the central village and along key trail sections, fed by gravity from a header tank supplied by the estate well. Channels are constructed in the Dutch tradition  -  narrow, stone-dressed, precisely levelled  -  running along path edges and through the village courtyard, with integrated misting points at intervals along the hottest summer trail sections. Water sounds throughout the estate: moving water at low volume is one of the most effective anxiety-reduction tools for both dogs and humans in high-stimulation environments.

The $45,000 cost covers approximately 400-600 linear metres of channel construction, the header tank and gravity-feed infrastructure, misting nozzle installation at 20-30 points along summer trail sections, and stone sourcing consistent with the perimeter wall aesthetic. The channels serve dogs directly  -  shallow, accessible, clean moving water at frequent intervals means dogs on trail walks are never more than a few minutes from a drink. The misting system extends the comfortable operating range for dogs in summer heat, reducing the weather-dependency of outdoor operations in July and August.

nodes.label: Arborsculpture / Living Tree Forms
nodes.description: A permanent, multi-decade living art program in which selected trees across the estate are trained into deliberate sculptural forms through repeated seasonal interventions  -  pleaching, espalier, grafting, weaving, and crown-shaping techniques that guide living wood over years and decades into arches, tunnels, woven groves, and council circles. The $12,000 node covers species selection and planting (whips and young trees positioned for training), basic tooling and training infrastructure, and engagement of an arborist or arborsculptor to establish the first cohort of forms and train the estate's land team in ongoing maintenance technique. Individual projects include: a pleached lime tunnel linking two trail sections (15-20 years to maturity), a woven hornbeam council circle for outdoor gatherings (8-12 years), espalier fruit walls on south-facing structures (productive within 3-5 years), and Loki's Arch  -  a dedicated living arch over the path to the estate's sacred ground, planted from day one and shaped across generations. Foster youth participate annually in training and maintenance, learning a craft that operates on timescales longer than any individual career. The $400 monthly covers the arborist's seasonal visits and materials.
nodes.perk: Program naming: "Tree Art Walk made possible by [Donor Name]"; sponsored individual "trained trees" with discreet tags; and optional "Founding Tree" dedication for the first completed form.

nodes.label: Firewood Sales
nodes.description: Production and sale of Maine-legal seasoned firewood from the estate's own forest management operations  -  primarily timber from trail clearing, wind damage, disease removal, and sustainable selective harvest. Output is measured and sold in Maine legal cords (128 cubic feet stacked, or the state-defined loose-thrown cord volumes for 12-16 inch lengths). The $8,000 covers chainsaw equipment, a log splitter, a seasoning rack system, and the initial firewood bay construction at the staging area. Annual production ceiling is estimated at approximately 130 cords per year, applying Maine's published woodland growth benchmark of one-third cord per acre per year to 400 acres  -  though actual yield depends heavily on stand conditions, harvest plan, and the volume of incidental timber from trail and infrastructure work. At 2026 Maine retail prices of $350-$500 per cord, maximum annual revenue is $45,500-$65,000. In practice, firewood production is a byproduct of land stewardship rather than a primary activity  -  the estate is clearing and managing forest for ecological and operational reasons, and firewood sales convert that necessary work into revenue rather than disposal cost.
nodes.perk: "Founding Woodheat Program made possible by [Donor Name]"; donor plaque at the firewood bay; sponsor-tagged "Season Firewood made possible by [Donor Name]" on the public tree.

nodes.label: Chaga Programme
nodes.description: Chaga (Inonotus obliquus) is a slow-growing parasitic fungus found on birch trees across the Northern Hemisphere, harvested and brewed as a medicinal and culinary tea for centuries across Scandinavia and Russia. New Doggerland's Maine forest contains mature birch stands  -  a natural substrate for both wild harvest and cultivated inoculation. The $15,000 node covers inoculation of selected birch trees with chaga spawn, establishment of a sustainable wild-harvest rotation protocol for naturally occurring chaga on the property, and basic drying and processing infrastructure for an on-site product. Chaga grows slowly  -  harvestable concentrations on inoculated trees take 7-15 years to establish, though wild harvest of existing chaga can begin from day one on appropriate stands. Once productive, the program yields a genuinely premium, estate-grown ingredient feeding directly into Gingerworks (chaga ginger beer is the brewery's signature product), the restaurant, and a retail product line. Annual income at full production: $200,000-$300,000. No income is expected in years 1-6; this is a long-horizon investment consistent with the institution's time horizon.
nodes.perk: Program naming: "Chaga Program made possible by [Donor Name]", acknowledgment on the program page.

nodes.label: Transport Fleet
nodes.description: A fleet of purpose-built large-scale rescue transport vehicles  -  the first of which costs $1,200,000, with subsequent units at approximately $900,000 each, targeting a full fleet of 12. Each vehicle is a self-contained mobile rescue operation: dog compartments sized for comfort over transport efficiency (crates above minimum standard, climate controlled, acoustically dampened), a dedicated veterinary care area with examination surface, medication storage, and emergency treatment capability, a structured exercise corridor allowing dogs to move and decompress during long transits, staff sleeping bunks for multi-day operations, and a small kitchen and mess area. The fleet's primary function is large-scale rescue operations  -  interstate shelter transfers, natural disaster response, hoarding case extractions, and any situation requiring the safe movement of dozens of dogs simultaneously over long distances. At full fleet strength, New Doggerland can mobilise a coordinated transport operation capable of moving 120-200 dogs in a single deployment. Each vehicle is also a named donor opportunity at the highest tier  -  $900,000-$1,200,000 gifts that are among the most tangible single-donor contributions the organization can offer. Total fleet cost at 12 vehicles: approximately $11,100,000.

nodes.label: The Jewel
nodes.description:
A single integrated aquatic district where humans and dogs share water in parallel  -  the only facility of its kind anywhere. The design language is forest lagoon, not theme park concrete. The Jewel feels found rather than built: warm light on water, timber and stone, moss at the edges, trees visible through the envelope. It is the crown of New Doggerland and the primary reason guests book in February.
Spatial core. A central lagoon spine runs the length of the facility, visually unifying the district and anchoring three concentric rings of intensity. The zero-stress ring  -  shallow, warm, acoustically quiet  -  serves seniors, toddlers, and anxious dogs simultaneously. The play ring offers moderate energy and structured features. The high-energy ring contains slides, currents, distance fetch lanes, and athletic elements. Each ring is accessible from the central spine and clearly distinguished by surface treatment, sound level, and staffing density.
Signature experiences. The Aqua Fetch Bay is the anchor attraction  -  a fan-shaped splash zone with fixed forward-facing launch systems, drift capture geometry, non-slip docks, and one-dog-at-a-time release controls for long-range lanes. It is the indoor realization of the Extreme Fetch Field, scaled for a controlled aquatic environment. Two parallel lazy rivers run side by side  -  a human river with tubes and a dog current loop with gentle flow, stepped entry, and frequent exits  -  separated by transparent barriers so families remain visually together without uncontrolled mixing. Calm Cove decompression pools sit off the main spine: acoustically damped, minimal splashing, trauma-informed design for nervous dogs and guests who need a quieter water experience. A shallow forest beach provides gradual entry for both species, with clear zoning and staff-managed gates.
Safety and control. Hard zoning with soft visibility  -  physical separation where safety demands it, sightlines preserved throughout so families never lose visual contact across zones. Non-slip surfaces and paw-safe traction everywhere, no algae-prone materials in high-contact zones. One-way dog circulation in busy areas eliminates face-to-face bottlenecks. Frequent ramps, steps, and side egress points ensure no human or dog is ever trapped in a water flow. Eligibility gates at zone entries enforce height, swim ability, and dog temperament categories, with live staff authority to route guests at any point.
Sensory and aesthetic qualities. Timber, stone, mossy edges, and low-profile structures throughout. Night identity built on warm, low-glare lighting that reflects on water without stadium effect. Sound discipline in the calm ring: water features tuned to suppress constant high-frequency splash noise, creating a genuinely restful acoustic environment within a large wet facility.
Operational backbone. Overlapping lifeguard and dog-guard station coverage with no blind spots. Dog life jacket library and fit-check points at all water entries. Warm rinse and drying corridor for dogs before re-entering guest areas. Water quality regime designed explicitly for mixed-use realities  -  real-time monitoring per zone with rapid independent closure capability. No zone's closure requires shutting the facility.
nodes.perk: Facility naming: "The Jewel made possible by [Donor Name]", permanent donor plaque at the main entrance, and a named element within the facility  -  the Aqua Fetch Bay, the central lagoon spine, or the shallow forest beach  -  for the lead sponsor.

nodes.label: Disc Golf Course
nodes.description: An 18-hole public disc golf course routed through the estate's forest, built primarily with community volunteer labor. New Doggerland supplies the purchased inputs: professional-grade steel basket targets at $300-$500 each (18 required = $5,400-$9,000), tee pad materials ($100-$200 per hole), signage, and scorecards  -  with the $4,000 allocation covering ND's direct cost contribution. The volunteer labor component (typically 200-400 hours for an 18-hole layout) is contributed by local disc golf clubs and community members who benefit from free ongoing access. Course design routes through the most scenic sections of the forest, using natural terrain  -  elevation changes, water crossings, dense tree corridors  -  as design elements. Day passes are $5-$8; play is free for estate guests. A course that would cost $40,000-$80,000 commercially is delivered for $4,000 through community partnership  -  the model New Doggerland applies across all community amenity nodes where local engagement can substitute for capital outlay.
nodes.perk: Course naming: "Disc Golf Course made possible by [Donor Name]", acknowledgment on the course map and tee markers.

nodes.label: Forest Golf Course
nodes.description: An 18-hole forest golf course routed through the estate using minimal clearance  -  designed to work with the existing tree canopy rather than clear it. Each hole consists of a large metal bell suspended from a low timber frame; a hole is completed by striking the bell rather than sinking a ball in a cup, eliminating the need for maintained greens and making the course genuinely all-weather and low-maintenance. Players navigate the forest with a club and ball, completing the course by sound  -  the ring of a struck bell carrying through the trees. The course can be reconfigured seasonally by relocating the bell frames, providing variety for returning guests without additional construction. A basic roofed staging pavilion at the start holds rental clubs and balls and provides weather shelter for group tee-off. Play price is $12 per round with optional club and ball rental; free for estate guests. At 20-40 rounds per day during peak season, the course generates $25,000-$60,000 annually. Minimal ongoing maintenance cost  -  no greens, no fairway mowing, no irrigation.
nodes.perk: Course naming: "Forest Golf Course made possible by [Donor Name]", sponsor plaque at the staging pavilion.

nodes.label: Public Dog Park
nodes.description: A purpose-built public off-leash dog park occupying 0.5 acres, designed to the highest standard of dog park infrastructure and open to the public at no charge. Two separated activity zones  -  one for large and high-energy dogs, one for small and senior dogs  -  are enclosed within a double-airlock entry fencing system preventing escape during entry and exit. Surface is shredded wood mulch over compacted base for drainage and cushioning. The park includes a covered shelter pavilion with handler seating, four water stations with dog-height bowls and human-height taps, picnic tables and benches, waste bag dispensers and lidded bins at all entry points, tick-check stations, and a full commercial agility equipment set  -  A-frame, tunnel, weave poles, jump bars, and pause table  -  integrated into the large-dog zone. The $185,000 covers land clearing, grading and drainage, double-airlock perimeter fencing, internal zone divider, pavilion construction, mulch surfacing, equipment, and all fixtures. The public dog park is New Doggerland's primary community-facing asset in Phase 1  -  free, welcoming, and visible before the resort opens. It is the first reason a local family with a dog has to visit, and the first experience that builds the local reputation the organization depends on.
nodes.perk: Park naming: "Public Dog Park made possible by [Donor Name]", donor plaque on the pavilion, and named agility elements (e.g., "Weave Poles made possible by [Donor Name]") for secondary donors. "Founding Day" first-use ceremony for the primary sponsor.

nodes.label: Adventure Playground
nodes.description: A timber-built adventure playground in the tradition of the 1990s European adventure playground  -  large, physical, genuinely challenging, and integrated into real forest terrain rather than safety-surfaced flat ground. Built across 0.25 acres with the estate's resident woodworker as lead builder, the playground uses the forest's own trees, roots, slopes, and natural features as structural elements alongside built timber structures. The $135,000 covers timber materials, hardware, safety surfacing in fall zones, perimeter fencing, a parent shelter pavilion with seating and weather cover, water stations, tick-check points, and the woodworker's construction time. Structures include a multi-level timber fort with rope traverses and cargo net climbs, a lookout deck sited in an existing tree, a balance and agility trail using logs and stumps, a supervised fire pit area for older children, and a mud kitchen. The playground is for children, but dogs on lead are welcome in the parent area throughout. Age guidance rather than age restrictions  -  parents assess their own child's capability. The 1990s design ethic is deliberate: real risk, real reward, real forest.
nodes.perk: Park naming: "Adventure Playground made possible by [Donor Name]", sponsor plaque on the parent shelter, and named major elements (e.g., "Timber Fort made possible by [Donor Name]", "Rope Traverse made possible by [Donor Name]") for secondary donors.

nodes.label: SAR Training Area
nodes.description: A designated search and rescue (SAR) training area positioned on the least mission-critical land on the estate  -  marginal terrain unsuitable for sanctuary, villa, or primary amenity use that becomes highly valuable when given a specific purpose. The $36,000 covers a 6-car gravel parking lot (accessible directly from the access road without entering the main estate), a simple covered staging area with a picnic table and power hookup, basic fencing enclosing approximately one acre of varied terrain, and entry signage. The area is made available to local SAR teams, fire department search units, and K9 units at no charge in exchange for relationship, goodwill, and the political capital that comes from being the organization that gave the county's SAR teams a permanent training ground. First responders who train on-site know the layout, the terrain, and the staff  -  when New Doggerland eventually needs emergency access at 300+ acres with dogs, children, and vulnerable guests, the response will be faster and better than for any other rural property of comparable size. The community relationship is the primary return. The SAR area is also New Doggerland's most credible political investment at the local government level.
nodes.perk: Area naming: "SAR Training Area made possible by [Donor Name]" on the entry sign, plus a donor plaque at the staging area.

nodes.label: Archery field
nodes.description: A timber-framed, roofed shooting structure with seating for up to 10 archers, opening onto two isolated firing lanes separated by heavy timber baffles. Lane lengths are set at 10m and 20m to accommodate beginners through intermediate shooters. A mix of 3D animal targets and traditional bag targets are rotated seasonally. Equipment rental is available on-site  -  recurve bows in multiple draw weights, arrows, and armguards  -  making the range accessible to first-time visitors. A $10 day pass covers unlimited shooting; rental gear is additional. Dog-friendly  -  dogs must be leashed and far behind the shooting line.
nodes.perk: Range naming: "Archery Range made possible by [Donor Name]", sponsor plaque at the roofed structure entrance, and named lane markers for secondary donors.

nodes.label: Food forest
nodes.description: A long-horizon program establishing dozens of perennial food plant species throughout the estate  -  integrated into the forest, trail edges, clearings, and open zones rather than concentrated in a single growing area. The $6,000 covers initial seed stock, rhizomes, and bare-root plants across a curated species list selected for Maine hardiness, perennial habit, and nutritional or ecological value: salsify, Jerusalem artichoke, yarrow, wild strawberry, lamb's lettuce, dead nettle, sea kale, fat hen, lovage, French corn salad, good King Henry, Alexanders, Welsh onion, comfrey, tepary beans, scorzonera, and quince among others. Planting begins in Phase 1 and continues every season indefinitely. The design principle is discovery rather than garden: plants are sited along trails, beside water features, and in clearings so visitors encounter abundance without it appearing managed. In thirty years, a guest walking the trail network will move through a genuinely food-productive forest that appears entirely natural. The $500 monthly covers seasonal planting, propagation, and management by the land stewardship team and foster youth participants.
nodes.perk: Area naming: "Food Forest made possible by [Donor Name]", acknowledgment on trail interpretive signage.

nodes.label: Cross-country ski trails
nodes.description: Weather-permitting seasonal activation of 8+ miles of the existing trail network as groomed cross-country ski loops, operating December through February in Southern Maine when snowfall and temperatures allow. The $16,000 covers trail widening and low-branch clearing where existing paths require it, winter-specific directional signage and trail markers, a track-setter attachment for the estate's UTV to groom classic ski tracks after snowfall, and equipment rental infrastructure at the trailhead  -  classic and skate skis in multiple sizes, poles, and boot adapters. Two circuits are offered: a 3 km beginner loop and a 6 km intermediate loop. The beginner loop doubles as the dog skijoring program's dedicated circuit during designated time windows. Classic and skate-ski variants are offered where trail width allows. Monthly operational costs during the ski season include grooming after each significant snowfall, equipment maintenance, and trailhead staffing. Day pass $15; equipment rental additional. Free for estate guests. The program is weather-dependent by nature  -  Southern Maine winters are variable, and some seasons will offer more operating days than others  -  but the infrastructure investment is modest enough that a partial season still justifies the cost.
