nodes.perk: Season naming: "Cross-Country Ski Season made possible by [Donor Name]", sponsor acknowledgment on the trail map and trailhead signage, and a named rest shelter or warming bench on the course.

nodes.label: Dog Skijoring
nodes.description:
A dedicated dog skijoring program running on the beginner cross-country ski loop, where a skier is harnessed to one or two dogs via a bungee towline and pulled through the forest trail. New Doggerland provides harness and towline rental, a short orientation session, and a designated skijoring-only time window on the beginner loop to prevent conflicts with unattached skiers. The program is open to all guests  -  those bringing their own dogs rent equipment and go, while first-timers can book an orientation session.
Skijoring has a discovery problem, not a product problem. Most visitors will not know what it is when they arrive. A single visible session on the trail  -  a dog surging ahead, a skier flying through the pines  -  is the only marketing required. Once seen, it is immediately wanted. Expect slow uptake in year one and a meaningfully different picture by year three as it becomes one of the estate's signature winter activities.
The program also runs with sanctuary dogs assessed as suitable for the activity. For high-energy rescue dogs, structured skijoring sessions provide outlet, improve temperament assessment accuracy, and increase adoptability. For potential adopters, a skijoring session with a sanctuary dog they are considering is among the most powerful pre-adoption bonding experiences the estate can offer  -  a guest who has run a mile through a Maine forest behind that dog is not a hesitant adopter. Staff supervision is required for all sanctuary dog pairings.
nodes.perk: Program naming: "Skijoring Program made possible by [Donor Name]", sponsor acknowledgment on the rental equipment and trail signage, and an invitation to the inaugural skijoring session.

nodes.label: Orienteering courses
nodes.description: Two permanent orienteering courses laid out across the trail network using weatherproof marker posts and laminated control cards  -  a beginner loop of approximately 2 km and an intermediate course of approximately 5 km. Course maps are printed in-house and available at the trailhead kiosk at no charge. The $4,500 covers marker posts, laminated control cards, map design and printing, and a digital course-setting system allowing seasonal course variation without replacing hardware. A dog-friendly variant  -  "dog-O"  -  runs controls at nose height along dog-accessible routes, designed for off-leash running with a handler following a map. Seasonal score-O events are open to the public at no charge, building local community engagement with the trail network. Orienteering has a discovery problem  -  most visitors don't know what it is until they try it  -  but a single completed beginner course typically converts a first-timer into a returning participant. The estate's varied terrain, forest density, and 15+ miles of trail network make it an unusually good orienteering venue.
nodes.perk: Course naming: "Orienteering Courses made possible by [Donor Name]", sponsor acknowledgment on all printed course maps, and a named control post at the start/finish point.

nodes.label: Community BMX track
nodes.description: A dirt BMX track built primarily with community volunteer labor on marginal estate land, with New Doggerland supplying the purchased inputs: imported fill or soil amendments where terrain requires it, erosion control fabric and matting on key berms and jumps, any rented equipment time for compaction and shaping, basic entry signage, and safety delineation at the track perimeter. The $16,000 covers ND's direct cost contribution; the design, shaping, and construction labor is contributed by local BMX riders and clubs who benefit from a permanent free-to-use facility. A well-designed beginner-to-intermediate BMX track typically includes a starting hill, 4-6 rhythm sections, 2-3 bermed corners, and a finishing straight  -  achievable on 0.25-0.5 acres of suitable terrain. The track is maintained by the community that built it, with ND providing materials for seasonal repairs. Free to use, no booking required. Dogs on lead permitted in the spectator area.
nodes.perk: Track naming: "BMX Track made possible by [Donor Name]"; named start hill or named feature zones for secondary donors; sponsor plaque at the entry sign.

nodes.label: Off-leash trail
nodes.description: A dedicated fenced off-leash trail loop providing fully enclosed, gate-secured off-leash running for dogs whose owners want the freedom of off-leash movement without the open terrain of the broader estate. The 0.5-mile loop is 50 feet wide  -  two parallel fence lines creating a generous corridor rather than a narrow run  -  with double-gate airlock entries at each end preventing escape during entry and exit. The $74,000 covers fencing and gate hardware for the full perimeter (approximately 5,800 linear feet of fencing at two fence lines), airlock gate construction, trail surface preparation within the corridor, rules and safety signage at both entry points, and basic tick-control stations. The loop is bookable for a fee, giving a single party exclusive use for a defined time window  -  preventing the uncontrolled dog-to-dog encounters that make standard off-leash areas stressful for reactive dogs or anxious owners. For guests with dogs that cannot safely be off-leash in open environments, this is the most important amenity on the estate.
nodes.perk: Loop naming: "Off-Leash Trail made possible by [Donor Name]", named airlock gates, and sponsor plaques at each entry sign.

nodes.label: On-site Camping
nodes.description: Private, fenced, dog-safe camping plots distributed through the estate, each a quarter acre with a level pad, fire ring, picnic table, power hookup, and direct trail access. Sites are fully enclosed with dog-safe fencing and a latching gate  -  guests can set up camp and let their dogs roam freely within the site without supervision. The shared sanitation block provides toilets, showers, and dog wash stations. Plots are bookable by the night or week. A minimum of 6 sites are required to open the campground; the repeatable pad system allows the campground to scale to 25 sites as demand grows.
nodes.perk: Campground naming: "Campground made possible by [Donor Name]", permanent plaque at the campground entrance, and optional named individual sites for secondary donors.

nodes.label: Basic Sanitation Block
nodes.description: A permanent, year-round sanitation block serving campers, day visitors, and staff. The facility contains 12 unisex self-contained toilet stalls, 4 shower stalls, 2 kitchen sink areas for food prep and washing up, and 2 raised dog wash stations with warm water, restraint bars, and drainage. All stalls are ADA-width to accommodate mobility aids and families with dogs. Construction is timber-frame with durable tile throughout, forced ventilation, and a heating system sized for Maine winters. The dog wash stations are open to all visitors  -  not gated behind a paid tier  -  and positioned at the facility entrance for easy trail access. Hot water is supplied by an on-demand system to handle peak morning demand from the campground.
nodes.perk: Facility naming: "Bathhouse made possible by [Donor Name]", permanent donor plaque at the entrance, and named dog wash stations for secondary donors.

nodes.label: Founder Family Home
nodes.description: A temporary but fully functional founder residence suitable for a family of three, with a dedicated volunteer meeting area, mud room, internal capacity to foster 4 dogs while keeping 3 personal dogs, a securely fenced yard sized for extended unsupervised dog time, and an on-site sewage solution via a conventional septic system.
nodes.perk: Dwelling naming: "Founder Base Cabin made possible by [Donor Name]", plaque in the meeting area, and a named dog yard gate sign ("Canine Yard made possible by [Donor Name]").

nodes.label: Mushroom Grove
nodes.description: Hardwood logs sourced from trail clearing operations are inoculated with culinary mushroom spawn  -  primarily lion's mane, oyster, and shiitake  -  and laid in shaded forest rows to fruit over a 12-24 month establishment period. A designated Mushroom Grove of 200-400 logs is integrated into the trail network as both a productive harvest site and a visitor-facing educational feature. Harvest is sold through the on-site snackbar, to local restaurants, and at farmers markets. Trail-clearing waste that would otherwise be chipped or removed is converted directly into a revenue stream, with near-zero material cost. No income is expected in year 1, modest yield in year 2, and full production from year 3.
nodes.perk: "Mushroom Grove made possible by [Donor Name]"; sponsor-tagged log clusters with small carved markers; plaque at the grove entry point; and "Founding Harvest" acknowledgment  -  the first commercial harvest batch is labeled with the sponsor's name.

nodes.label: Forest Daycare
nodes.description: A licensed outdoor forest childcare program operating year-round on the estate in the Scandinavian friluftsliv tradition  -  there is no bad weather, only bad clothing. Children spend the majority of each session outdoors in the forest regardless of conditions, engaged in unstructured and semi-structured nature play under the supervision of qualified outdoor educators. Activities center on what the forest offers: building, foraging, fire-making under supervision, mud, water, weather, animals, and time. No screens. No structured curriculum. Children learn to assess risk, tolerate discomfort, and find their own entertainment in a landscape that rewards attention. The program operates at the intersection of the estate's mission and its community function  -  available to resort guests with young children, to local families on a sessional basis, and to foster youth and DV survivor families at no cost under the BOGO model. Dogs are present throughout, integrated naturally into the outdoor environment. Maine's climate makes this a genuine year-round commitment. Winter sessions are the point, not the exception  -  children in appropriate kit in a Maine winter forest, building snow shelters and tracking animals, is the experience. Parents who have never seen a child genuinely absorbed for four hours in a forest with no devices will not forget it. Licensing requirements in Maine for outdoor childcare programs will require legal review before launch  -  staff ratios, qualifications, and site requirements vary from standard center-based care.
nodes.perk: Program naming: "Forest School made possible by [Donor Name]", permanent plaque at the program's base area, and an invitation to the inaugural first session.

nodes.label: Sledding Hill with Rope Tow
nodes.description: A natural sledding hill selected for gradient, run length, and safe run-out, maintained through seasonal preparation and served by a rope tow for the uphill return. The $18,000 covers hill clearing and grading, rope tow installation (electric motor, continuous loop, handle grips), safety fencing on the lateral flanks, a small warming shelter at the base with bench seating and boot storage, and sled rental inventory (20-30 toboggans and foam sleds). The hill is operational when natural snow depth and consistency allow  -  typically December through February in Southern Maine, with significant year-to-year variation. Dogs are permitted in the run-out and spectator areas but not on the active hill during operational hours. Free for estate guests; $8 day pass for public visitors. The sledding hill is one of the estate's least expensive winter amenities and consistently one of the most popular with families  -  the return on $18,000 in community goodwill and guest satisfaction is disproportionate to the investment.
nodes.perk: Hill naming: "Sledding Hill made possible by [Donor Name]", sponsor plaque at the base structure, and an invitation to the inaugural first run of the season.

nodes.label: Treehouse Network
nodes.description:
A network of connected treehouses distributed through the forest canopy at 4-6 metre height, linked by rope bridges, cargo net traverses, and platform walkways to form a continuous elevated trail approximately 200 metres in total length. The $25,000 cost covers structural engineering assessment of suitable host trees, platform construction in pressure-treated timber, safety railing and netting throughout, the rope bridge and traverse connections between platforms, and lighting for evening use.

The treehouse network serves multiple populations simultaneously. For children it is straightforward adventure infrastructure  -  the elevated perspective, the movement between platforms, and the mild exposure to height delivering the kind of risk-calibrated play that developmental research consistently identifies as beneficial and that most modern playgrounds no longer provide. For adults it is an unusual trail experience with a genuine view into the forest canopy. For dogs on the ground below, the movement and sounds of people overhead is a novel enrichment stimulus. The network is sited above a section of the dog trail network so that guests can walk at two levels simultaneously  -  one party in the trees, their dog on the path below, watching each other through the canopy.

nodes.label: Restaurant #1
nodes.description: New Doggerland's primary on-site restaurant  -  a full-service, dog-friendly dining room seating 60-80 covers, operating year-round as the culinary heart of the central village. The $250,000 covers commercial kitchen fitout to Maine health code standard, dining room with dog-friendly flooring and under-table anchoring points at every table, bar area, and outdoor terrace. The menu is built around ingredients foraged, grown, or produced on the estate: mushrooms from the Mushroom Grove, wild herbs and greens from the food forest, firewood-grilled meats over estate-cut hardwood, chaga and ginger from the estate gardens, and Dutch-influenced specials reflecting the founder's heritage. The kitchen team works directly with the land stewardship team on seasonal availability  -  the menu changes genuinely with what the forest and gardens produce. Dogs sit under the table on the same booking as their owners with no special arrangement required. Lunch and dinner daily; breakfast when villa occupancy justifies staffing. The restaurant is also the primary venue for the Long Table dinner and private events.
nodes.perk: Restaurant naming: "Restaurant made possible by [Donor Name]", permanent donor plaque at the entrance.

nodes.label: ADA Accessible Trails
nodes.description: Two miles of fully ADA-compliant accessible forest trail, surfaced with compacted crushed limestone or packed gravel to a width of 8-10 feet, with grades not exceeding 5% (1:20) on primary routes and cross-slopes under 2%. Designed for wheelchairs, mobility aids, strollers, and visitors with limited mobility. Includes rest areas with level pull-offs every quarter mile, interpretive signage at accessible heights, two accessible picnic areas, and dog waste stations throughout. Routes are selected to pass through the most scenic sections of the estate. The trail connects the main parking lot directly to the sanctuary viewing area and the forest edge, ensuring the core New Doggerland experience is available to all visitors regardless of mobility.
nodes.perk: Trail naming: "Accessible Trail made possible by [Donor Name]", permanent donor plaque at the accessible trailhead, acknowledgment on all trail maps and the estate website, and a named rest area along the route.

nodes.label: Rescue Goat Enclosure (Up to 12 Goats)
nodes.description: A purpose-built rescue goat enclosure providing permanent sanctuary for up to 12 goats, sized to welfare standards well above the industry minimum. Indoor shelter provides 20-25 sq ft per goat (approximately 300 sq ft total) with bedded floor, natural ventilation, and access to a contained activity yard. The yard provides species-appropriate foraging, climbing, and social space with goat-proof perimeter fencing, double-gate entry, automatic or gravity-fed water system, hay racks and mineral feeders, and an electric deterrent perimeter where predator pressure warrants it. The $20,300 covers all construction, fencing, water infrastructure, and initial equipment. The goat herd serves multiple simultaneous functions: permanent sanctuary for animals with nowhere else to go, land management through browsing of invasive species on rotated sections of the estate, therapeutic trail companionship for guests, and an educational resource for foster youth and agricultural college students learning animal husbandry. Monthly costs of $1,500 cover feed, farrier, veterinary care, and bedding.
nodes.perk: "Goat Sanctuary made possible by [Donor Name]" on the entry sign, plus a permanent plaque at the main gate; optional named elements (shelter, water station) for secondary donors.

nodes.label: Rescue Donkey facility
nodes.description: Initial donkey sanctuary infrastructure sized for 8 animals  -  the founding herd of what becomes a permanent, governance-protected multi-decade commitment. The facility provides at least 4 acres of grazing, at least 400 sq ft of covered bedded shelter, perimeter fencing, secure gates, and an all-season water system. The $55,000 covers all construction and infrastructure; monthly costs of $1,500 cover feed, farrier services every 8-12 weeks, routine veterinary care, and bedding. Donkeys at New Doggerland serve as permanent sanctuary residents, trail companions for guests, therapeutic presences for anxious dogs in the adjacent sanctuary, and working partners for foster youth and agricultural college students. Their 25-40 year lifespans make every animal that arrives a decades-long commitment  -  a fact encoded in the governance documents, which protect the donkey facility from decommissioning or reduction for cost-saving purposes. The Rescue Donkey Facility Upgrade node later doubles this capacity to 16 animals, at which point the herd also becomes a meaningful predator deterrent for the goat and duck enclosures.
nodes.perk: Facility naming: "Donkey Sanctuary made possible by [Donor Name]", donor plaque at the main gate, and optional named elements (shelter nameplate, water station plaque) for secondary donors.

nodes.label: Well and permanent water
nodes.description: Surveying, permitting, drilling, and full installation of a permanent on-site drilled well, sized to serve the founder home, volunteer staging area, animal care facilities, and early public operations. Includes pressure tank, pump, filtration system, and distribution manifold. Retires the temporary water delivery system and IBC storage tanks from the Temporary Water node, establishing the estate's permanent potable water supply. Well depth and yield vary by site geology  -  Southern Maine typically returns 50-200 ft depth with 3-10 GPM yield, sufficient for early operational demands.
nodes.perk: "Founding Water Infrastructure made possible by [Donor Name]", permanent donor plaque at the wellhead housing, and acknowledgment on the estate's infrastructure transparency page.

nodes.label: Villa Design Contest
nodes.description:
An open international design competition inviting architects, designers, and design students to submit proposals for the New Doggerland villa typology. The brief specifies: single-storey or split-level, dog-forward spatial design, forest integration, thermal performance for Maine winters, natural materials consistent with the estate aesthetic, and a minimum private outdoor enclosure. A jury of architects, welfare experts, and the Founder Steward evaluates submissions on welfare integration, aesthetic coherence, buildability, and long-horizon durability. The winning design becomes the template for the first 10 villas. Runner-up designs may be adapted for later phases. The contest itself generates significant press coverage and positions New Doggerland as a serious design-forward institution before a single villa is built.
Prize structure:

First place: $50,000 + build commission
Second place: $15,000
Third place: $7,500
Student prize: $5,000
nodes.perk: Competition naming: "Villa Design Prize made possible by [Donor Name]", acknowledgment on all competition materials and press releases, jury seat offer (non-binding on outcome), and permanent acknowledgment on the winning villa type plaque.

nodes.label: Central Village Design Contest
nodes.description:
An open international design competition inviting architects, urban designers, and landscape architects to propose the layout, architecture, and material language of New Doggerland's central village  -  the estate's permanent civic and commercial hub. The brief specifies: dog-forward spatial design throughout all public areas, natural materials consistent with the estate aesthetic, year-round operability in Maine's climate, integration with the surrounding forest rather than clearance of it, and a compact walkable layout that serves guests, staff, artisan partners, and mission visitors without hierarchy or visible distinction between them. The village must feel discovered rather than built  -  arrived at through the forest, not approached across a car park.
A jury of architects, landscape designers, welfare experts, and the Founder Steward evaluates submissions on spatial coherence, aesthetic integration, buildability, long-horizon durability, and dog-forward design innovation. The winning scheme becomes the design framework for the Central Village build. Runner-up schemes may inform individual building or landscape elements.
Prize structure:

First place: $65,000 + design development commission
Second place: $20,000
Third place: $10,000
Student prize: $7,500
nodes.perk: Competition naming: "Central Village Design Prize made possible by [Donor Name]", acknowledgment on all competition materials and press releases, jury seat offer (non-binding on outcome), and permanent acknowledgment on the Central Village entry marker.

nodes.label: The Jewel Design Contest
nodes.description:
An international design competition for The Jewel  -  New Doggerland's flagship integrated human and dog aquatic district, and the only facility of its kind anywhere in the world. The competition brief is specific and demanding: a forest lagoon, not a theme park; a building that feels found rather than built; a single aquatic district where humans and dogs share water in parallel with controlled togetherness and hard separation only where safety genuinely requires it.
The brief specifies the full spatial program  -  central lagoon spine, three rings of intensity from zero-stress to high-energy, Aqua Fetch Bay as anchor attraction, parallel lazy rivers with transparent separation, Calm Cove decompression pools, and a shallow forest beach with staff-managed zoning. It specifies the safety architecture  -  hard zoning with soft visibility, one-way dog circulation, paw-safe non-slip surfaces throughout, frequent multi-species egress, eligibility gates at zone transitions, and overlapping lifeguard and dog-guard coverage with no blind spots. It specifies the sensory and aesthetic standards  -  timber, stone, mossy edges, low-profile structures, warm low-glare night lighting, and sound discipline in the calm ring sufficient to create a genuinely restful acoustic environment within a large wet facility. It specifies the operational backbone  -  dog life jacket library, warm rinse and drying corridor, real-time per-zone water quality monitoring with independent closure capability.
Submissions are evaluated on how convincingly a team resolves the central design problem: making humans and dogs feel genuinely together in water, at scale, safely. Teams that default to full separation or to uncontrolled mixing will not be shortlisted. The solution space is narrow and genuinely difficult. The jury expects to be surprised.
The jury comprises architects, aquatic facility engineers, the Founder Steward, a dog behavior specialist, and one external accessibility consultant. The winning scheme becomes the design development brief for The Jewel build. Runner-up schemes may inform individual zone or feature design.

Prize structure:
* First place: $200,000 + design development commission
* Second place: $60,000
* Third place: $25,000
* Honorable mentions ×2: $10,000 each
* Student prize: $15,000
* Total prize pool: $320,000
nodes.perk: Competition naming: "Jewel Design Prize made possible by [Donor Name]", acknowledgment on all competition materials and international press releases, jury seat offer (non-binding on outcome), and permanent acknowledgment on The Jewel's entrance wall alongside the winning architect's credit.

nodes.label: Power upgrade
nodes.description: A capacity expansion of the estate's power infrastructure to support Phase 2 operational loads  -  primarily the sanctuary core's climate control, ventilation, lighting, and veterinary equipment, and the early central village build-out. The upgrade extends the Phase 1 solar array with additional panels and inverter capacity, expands battery storage to handle overnight and cloudy-day demand at full sanctuary load, and upgrades the site's internal distribution network with new circuits and increased panel capacity. A grid connection application is filed at this stage as a backup supply and emergency fallback  -  not as a primary source, but as a prudent contingency for Maine winters when solar yield drops significantly and sanctuary animal welfare cannot tolerate outages. The Phase 1 installation was sized for the founder home and volunteer staging area. This node sizes the system for an institution.
nodes.perk: "Power Infrastructure made possible by [Donor Name]" (expanded to cover the full system), updated donor plaque at the electrical room, and acknowledgment on the estate's infrastructure transparency page alongside the Phase 1 power sponsor if different.

nodes.label: Parking Lot
nodes.description: The estate's first formal parking facility  -  30-40 bays of compacted gravel providing organised vehicle access for day guests, volunteers, contractors, and staff during early operations. Bays are defined with timber edge restraints and gravel surfacing, sized for standard vehicles with two oversized accessible bays. Every bay includes a dedicated dog leashing post: a ground-set timber post with two leash rings at appropriate heights, positioned at the front corner of each bay so a guest can secure their dog the moment the car door opens. The $55,000 covers clearing and grading, compacted gravel surfacing, bay definition, drainage, and leashing post installation across all 35-40 bays. This is not a courtesy feature  -  it is the first physical statement that New Doggerland is designed around dogs as full participants in every arrival and departure. The Phase 3 Parking Lot Upgrade expands this facility to 400-450 paved bays with EV charging to serve 150 villas at full capacity.
nodes.perk: Lot naming: "Parking Lot made possible by [Donor Name]", plaque at the entry, and optional "Sponsor a Bay" recognition plaques (bay-numbered, tied to leashing posts) for secondary donors.

nodes.label: Sanctuary Rescue Core upgrade
nodes.description:
Expansion of the Phase 1 sanctuary from 12-dog initial capacity to a professional high-volume rescue and adoption facility capable of processing 250 dogs per year at the highest operational standards. This is the inflection point  -  the node that transforms New Doggerland from a credible small rescue into a serious regional institution.
The upgrade encompasses four major additions. First, a main kennel expansion to 80-100 individual housing units with indoor/outdoor runs, climate control, acoustic dampening, and natural light design  -  each unit above industry minimum in every dimension. Second, a dedicated intake and quarantine building with isolation kennels, exam rooms, and disease-control protocols sufficient for high-volume intake from multiple sources including transport fleet deliveries, local surrender, and disaster response. Third, a behavioral rehabilitation wing with separate play yards grouped by temperament and energy level, training rooms, decompression access, and long-term resident housing for dogs requiring extended behavioral work before adoption readiness. Fourth, a professional adoption center with multiple private meet-and-greet rooms, a public-facing lobby, and a staffed adoption counseling operation that treats every placement as a considered match rather than a transaction.
At 250 dogs per year, the on-site population at any given time runs 30-40 dogs simultaneously. The facility is designed for 1,000 per year at full build  -  this upgrade establishes the physical bones of that institution at a scale that can open, operate, and demonstrate excellence before the next expansion is funded.
Support infrastructure includes industrial-scale food prep and cold storage, laundry facilities rated for high daily volume, staff welfare areas, and supply storage sufficient for 90-day operational continuity.
nodes.perk: Facility naming: "Rescue Center made possible by [Donor Name]", permanent donor plaque at the main entrance, naming rights to individual wings available for secondary donors  -  intake building, behavioral wing, adoption center  -  each a named donor opportunity in their own right.

nodes.label: Sanctuary Rescue Core upgrade 2
nodes.description: The third and final phase of sanctuary expansion, bringing the facility to its full design capacity of 1,000 dogs processed per year  -  the number at which New Doggerland becomes a serious national rescue institution rather than a regional one. The $250,000 cost covers the final infrastructure additions required to activate the capacity established in the bones of the Phase 2 sanctuary upgrade: additional staffing areas, final kennel wing activation, behavioral program scaling, and the operational systems  -  intake software, adoption platform, transport fleet integration  -  required to manage 1,000-dog annual throughput with the same per-dog standard of care as the first 12. At 1,000 dogs per year and an average length of stay of 14-25 days, the on-site population at any given time is 40-70 dogs simultaneously. The adoption program at this scale places approximately 3 dogs per day, every day of the year. The sanctuary at this phase is no longer a facility with an adoption operation attached. It is a rescue institution with national reach, disaster response capability, and a transport fleet that can mobilise anywhere in the country.

nodes.label: Rescue Goat Enclosure upgrade (Up to 24 Goats)
nodes.description: Expansion of the goat sanctuary from 12 to 24 animals, doubling shelter capacity, yard space, water provision, and fencing to accommodate a full herd. The expanded enclosure is sized to support the goat program's core functions at scale: invasive species clearance across the estate's marginal land, therapeutic trail companionship, educational land stewardship for foster youth and agricultural college students, and the permanent sanctuary model for goats who have nowhere else to go. At 24 goats, the herd becomes a meaningful land management tool  -  a rotating clearance team capable of working through bittersweet, multiflora rose, and other invasives that would otherwise require machinery or herbicide. Sections of the estate are fenced off in rotation and the herd moved through them, converting marginal scrub into browse-cleared ground suitable for food forest planting or trail extension. The goats do not know they are working. They are simply eating, which is the point. The upgrade includes expanded indoor shelter space (~500 sq ft), additional yard fencing, a second water system, hay and mineral feeder expansion, and an electric deterrent perimeter where needed for predator pressure.
nodes.perk: Enclosure naming: "Goat Sanctuary made possible by [Donor Name]", permanent plaque at the main gate, and optional named elements  -  shelter nameplate, water station plaque  -  for secondary donors.

nodes.label: Rescue Donkey facility upgrade
nodes.description: Expansion of the donkey sanctuary from 8 to 16 animals, doubling grazing acreage to at least 8 acres, expanding covered bedded shelter to at least 800 sq ft, and upgrading fencing, gates, and all-season water infrastructure accordingly. At 16 donkeys, the facility operates at meaningful scale across all its functions simultaneously  -  permanent sanctuary for animals who have nowhere else to go, trail companionship program for guests, therapeutic presence for anxious dogs in the adjacent sanctuary, and a working partnership with foster youth and agricultural college students learning animal husbandry. Donkeys at this scale also become a genuine guard animal resource. A herd of 16 distributed across the estate's grazing areas provides meaningful predator deterrence for the goat and duck enclosures  -  donkeys are naturally territorial toward canids and will actively confront foxes and coyotes. This is not incidental; it is part of the integrated multi-species land stewardship model. At 25-40 year lifespans, every donkey that arrives at New Doggerland is a decades-long commitment. The governance documents reflect this  -  the donkey facility may not be decommissioned or reduced below its operating capacity for cost-saving purposes. These animals are here for life. Farrier services run every 8-12 weeks per animal. At 16 donkeys this becomes a scheduled, regular relationship with a contracted farrier  -  worth formalizing as a named artisan partnership rather than an ad-hoc booking.
nodes.perk: Facility naming: "Donkey Sanctuary made possible by [Donor Name]", donor plaque at the main gate, and optional named elements (shelter nameplate, water station plaque) for secondary donors.

nodes.label: Upgraded Trail Network
nodes.description:
A comprehensive upgrade of the Phase 1 trail network from hand-cut working paths to a mature, surfaced, multi-use trail system capable of supporting full resort operations. The Phase 1 network established the routes and cleared the corridors. This node finishes them  -  gravel surfacing on primary and access trails, proper drainage infrastructure throughout, timber bridges and boardwalks over wet crossings, wayfinding signage at all junctions, interpretive panels at key points, and benches at scenic intervals.
The upgrade also extends total trail mileage as villa development and estate operations reveal additional connectivity needs  -  linking villa clusters to the central village, connecting the goat and donkey grazing areas to the public trail loops, and establishing the groomed winter corridors that the cross-country ski and skating trail programs depend on. The underlying tread of the ski and skating trail network is prepared at this stage, even if grooming equipment and activation costs are captured in their own nodes.
Dog decompression trails  -  the quiet, low-stimulus natural surface routes used exclusively for sanctuary dogs  -  are extended and formally mapped, with scent-coded entry markers integrated with the scent coding system. Staff circulation routes are hardened for UTV access year-round. Emergency vehicle access is confirmed to all major structures.
The result is a trail network that functions as the circulatory system of a mature forest resort rather than the skeleton of one under construction.
nodes.perk: Trail network naming: "Trail Network made possible by [Donor Name]", acknowledgment on all trail maps and the main trailhead kiosk, and a named primary trailhead for the lead sponsor.

nodes.label: 4 Dog Foster Care
nodes.description: Pre-adoption foster care for up to four dogs simultaneously, hosted in the founder home  -  the earliest expression of New Doggerland's rescue mission before the sanctuary facility is built. The $2,000 setup covers initial supplies: crates, beds, enrichment toys, leads, and a basic veterinary intake kit. The $1,200 monthly covers food, veterinary care, worming, flea treatment, and behavioral support materials for the active foster cohort. Foster dogs are assessed, socialised, and matched with adopters through the founder's personal network and early adoption outreach. Average length of stay is 14-30 days. At four dogs continuously, the program processes 50-100 adoptions per year in this phase  -  modest in number but significant as proof of concept, generating the earliest adoption data, behavioral assessment experience, and community relationships that the full sanctuary will later scale. The founder home's dedicated dog yard, internal capacity for four foster dogs alongside three personal dogs, and mud room infrastructure are specified precisely to support this program from day one.
nodes.perk: Program naming: "Foster Care Program made possible by [Donor Name]", acknowledgment on the program page.

nodes.label: ADA trail upgrade
nodes.description: Four miles of fully paved ADA-compliant shared-use forest path  -  asphalt surface, 10-12 feet wide, with grades not exceeding 5% and cross-slopes under 2%. The $2,800,000 node upgrades the existing Phase 1 compacted gravel accessible trail to a permanent paved surface, dramatically expanding all-weather accessibility for guests with mobility limitations, families with strollers, and older visitors. At 10-12 feet wide, the path accommodates two wheelchair users passing simultaneously alongside a dog on lead  -  the minimum width for a genuinely functional shared-use accessible route. The route connects the main parking area to the central village, sanctuary viewing area, forest dining sites, and key scenic points of the trail network. The $600 monthly covers surface maintenance, seasonal crack repair, and drainage management. This node is the estate's most significant accessibility investment, and signals that New Doggerland's commitment to universal access extends well beyond minimum compliance.
nodes.perk: Trail naming: "ADA Trail made possible by [Donor Name]", permanent donor plaque at the accessible trailhead.

nodes.label: Ginger Garden
nodes.description:
A dedicated growing area establishing culinary and brewing ginger as a long-term perennial crop, integrated into the forest edge where partial shade and moisture retention suit the plant. Initial beds are sized to supply the future Gingerworks brewery and on-site food operations, with surplus sold fresh or as dried root through the snackbar and farmers markets. Ginger in Maine requires either cold-frame or polytunnel season extension  -  the beds are established with low-cost row cover and cold frames in year one, with a small heated propagation area to start rhizomes indoors before last frost. The garden doubles as a visitor-facing feature on the trail network, with interpretive signage explaining the crop-to-glass pathway that leads eventually to Gingerworks.
Yield timeline: no harvestable crop in year 1 (establishment only). Modest first harvest in year 2. Full productive yield from year 3 onward. Gingerworks remains a long-horizon unlock  -  this node plants the seed, not the brewery.
nodes.perk: "Founding Ginger Garden made possible by [Donor Name]", donor plaque at the garden entry, acknowledgment on the Gingerworks origin story (permanently, including if Gingerworks becomes a commercial brand), and a ceremonial "first rhizome planting" invitation for the primary sponsor.

nodes.label: Parking Lot Upgrade
nodes.description:
Expansion of the Phase 1 gravel lot from 30-40 bays to a full-scale paved parking facility sized for 150 villas at capacity plus day guest and staff demand  -  approximately 400-450 spaces total. The expansion retains the defining feature of the Phase 1 lot: a dedicated dog leashing post at every single bay, without exception. A guest arriving with a dog has somewhere to secure them safely the moment the car door opens, before bags are unloaded or children are gathered. This is not a courtesy feature  -  it is a design standard that reflects the estate's fundamental orientation toward dogs as full participants in every arrival and departure.
Surface is paved asphalt with defined bays, permeable edge treatment for stormwater, adequate lighting for year-round Maine darkness, and clearly marked accessible bays at minimum ADA ratio. EV charging infrastructure is installed at 10% of bays in this phase with conduit roughed in for full coverage  -  Maine's EV adoption trajectory makes this a near-term operational necessity rather than a luxury. A landscaped buffer separates the lot from the central village entry, so arriving guests move through a brief tree corridor before reaching the estate proper. The car disappears. The forest begins.
nodes.perk: Lot naming: "Arrival Court made possible by [Donor Name]", plaque at the main entry, and "Sponsor a Bay" recognition plaques on individual leashing posts for secondary donors  -  bay-numbered, permanent, low-profile.

nodes.label: Grand Entry
nodes.description: The estate's primary arrival building  -  a single-storey reception and welcome structure at the transition point between the parking area and the forest path leading to the central village. Functionally the Grand Entry handles guest check-in, issues RFID wristbands, provides orientation and trail maps, manages day visitor access control, holds luggage for early arrivals and late departures, and staffs a permanent concierge point during operating hours. The $1,000 cost is a placeholder pending specification through the Central Village Design Contest brief. At 150-villa capacity, the building must handle approximately 8-12 simultaneous check-ins on a Sunday afternoon changeover  -  sized accordingly, with dog-forward spatial design throughout. The arrival experience sets the register for everything that follows; the Grand Entry is where that register is first established. Natural materials, low profile, and an immediate sense that this place was designed to welcome dogs as much as people.
nodes.perk: Building naming: "Grand Entry made possible by [Donor Name]", permanent donor plaque at the entrance.

nodes.label: DV Survivor Program
nodes.description:
A structured safe-stay program for domestic violence survivors  -  providing temporary villa accommodation, trauma-informed care, and connection to support services, funded through the BOGO villa model. The program addresses one of the most documented barriers to leaving abusive situations: 48% of DV survivors delay leaving because of pets, and most emergency shelters do not accept animals. At New Doggerland, survivors arrive with their pets. The villa is theirs for the duration of the stay  -  the same quality, same amenities, same forest access as every other guest. No visible distinction. No charity wing. No institutional feel.

Referrals come through established partnerships with DV shelter networks  -  primarily the Maine Coalition to End Domestic Violence and affiliated regional organizations  -  and through trauma therapists and social workers. Participants are not publicly identified; confidentiality is structural, not just policy. The estate's 300-acre boundary, controlled access, and non-public location provide physical safety that urban shelters cannot replicate.

All guest-facing staff complete trauma-informed care training before the program launches. A dedicated program coordinator manages referral relationships, coordinates with support services, and provides a single point of contact for participants navigating next steps  -  housing, legal support, financial planning  -  during their stay. The estate's veterinary facility provides care for any pets arriving in need. If a survivor had to leave a pet behind, sanctuary dogs are available for companionship and, where appropriate, adoption.

The $35,000 setup covers trauma-informed staff training across all guest-facing roles, confidentiality protocol development, legal review of guest data handling, and referral partnership formalisation. The $8,000 monthly covers the program coordinator role and ongoing connection to support services. The program cannot be eliminated for cost-saving purposes.
nodes.perk: Program naming: "DV Survivor Program made possible by [Donor Name]", permanent acknowledgment on program materials (internal only  -  no public signage that would identify participants), and a private briefing on program outcomes for the lead sponsor annually.
nodes.potentialGrantRevenue: Federal Violence Against Women Act (VAWA) grants, state DV prevention funding, and private foundation grants focused on DV survivor support and pet-friendly housing. Estimated $80,000–$250,000/year at program maturity.

nodes.label: Youth Program Space
nodes.description:
A purpose-built single-storey program building providing the dedicated operational infrastructure for the Youth Out of Care Program  -  sited near the villa clusters but with its own identity, separate from the central village and not guest-facing. The $420,000 covers design and construction of a building housing: a program director's office and case management suite with private meeting rooms (staff:participant conversations require genuine privacy), a group session and workshop room sized for 15-20 participants, a quiet study area with desk space and reliable connectivity for participants in education programs, a life skills kitchen for cooking instruction and daily use, a small dedicated therapy room, and staff welfare facilities.

The building is designed to feel like a place people want to be  -  natural materials, good light, connection to the forest  -  not an institutional annex. Participants will spend significant portions of their day here over a 3-12 month program; the quality of the space is part of the therapeutic model. The $1,200 monthly covers utilities and maintenance.
nodes.perk: Building naming: "Youth Program Space made possible by [Donor Name]", permanent donor plaque at the building entrance, and a named room within the building  -  case management suite, group room, or study area  -  for secondary donors.

nodes.label: Youth Out of Care Program
nodes.description:
A residential transitional program for young people aged 18-25 who have aged out of the foster care system  -  providing temporary housing, employment training, educational pathways, trauma-informed support, and a permanent connection to New Doggerland as a community. This is not a vacation program. It is a life-launch infrastructure.

Participants live in standard estate villas for 3-12 months  -  the same quality as paying guests, in the same residential fabric, indistinguishable from other villa occupants. The message is deliberate: you deserve this. Not a dormitory, not a program facility, not a charity bed. A villa in a forest, for as long as you need it to find your footing.

During their stay, participants work on-site in rotations across sanctuary operations, resort hospitality, kitchen, land stewardship, and trade apprenticeships  -  building a genuine employment record and marketable skills portfolio. An educational coordinator navigates GED completion, trade school enrolment, and college access. Case managers (ratio 1:6) provide intensive individual support. The program operates on a "hire low, lose them high" philosophy: a participant who leaves for a better opportunity elsewhere is a program success, celebrated not mourned.

Referrals come through Maine DHHS, foster care agencies, and youth homelessness organizations. Participants are recruited before or immediately after their 18th birthday where possible  -  the goal is to intercept the cliff before the fall, not respond to it after.

The $65,000 setup covers program licensing and legal structure, initial staff recruitment, referral partnership development, and dog pairing protocol design. The $42,000 monthly covers a program director ($90,000/year), four case managers ($55,000 average), an educational coordinator ($52,000), and an employment coordinator ($52,000), with remaining budget for program materials and operations. Alumni receive lifelong connection to the estate through the Youth Program Dogs node.
nodes.perk: Program naming: "Youth Out of Care Program made possible by [Donor Name]", permanent acknowledgment on program materials, and an annual private outcome briefing for the lead sponsor.
nodes.potentialGrantRevenue: Federal transitional housing grants (HUD), workforce development funding (WIOA), state foster care support grants through Maine DHHS, and private foundation grants focused on youth homelessness and foster care transition. Estimated $150,000–$400,000/year at program maturity.

nodes.label: Youth Program Dogs
nodes.description:
The permanent animal bonding and lifelong support component of the Youth Out of Care Program  -  each participant who completes the program is paired with a rescue dog that is theirs to keep, with a commitment from New Doggerland to support that animal for the rest of its life.

The pairing is deliberate, not arbitrary. The sanctuary's behavioral assessment data, the participant's lifestyle, energy level, and housing trajectory, and the dog's temperament and needs are all considered. A participant moving into a small apartment with a shift-work schedule gets a different match than one heading into a rural placement. The match is made to last.

The lifelong support commitment covers everything: veterinary care at no cost at the estate's hospital, food through the Kustom Kibble program, supplies as needed, and crisis boarding if the participant faces a period of instability  -  job loss, temporary housing crisis, medical emergency  -  where the dog cannot be with them. The dog is never a financial burden. It is never surrendered because of poverty. New Doggerland commits to this animal for the duration of its natural life, regardless of what happens to the participant's circumstances.

At 25-30 program graduates per year, with an average dog lifespan of 12 years and annual support cost of approximately $2,000 per dog, the program's ongoing liability grows to approximately $600,000-$720,000 per year at full maturity  -  a figure that is accounted for in the generalFundMin and offset by grant funding and the Kustom Kibble program's donated-pound model. The $12,000 setup covers pairing protocol development, initial supply kits for graduating participants, and an alumni tracking system for ongoing support coordination. The $6,000 monthly covers active cohort and early alumni support, scaling as the alumni base grows.
nodes.perk: Program naming: "Youth Program Dogs made possible by [Donor Name]", permanent acknowledgment on program materials, and the option to sponsor a specific graduating participant's dog  -  named, photographed, with annual updates for the life of the animal.
nodes.potentialGrantRevenue: Human-animal bond research grants, animal welfare foundation grants, and private giving from donors motivated by the intersection of youth welfare and rescue dog adoption. Estimated $20,000–$60,000/year.

nodes.label: Estate Vehicle Fleet
nodes.perk: Fleet naming: "Estate Vehicle Fleet made possible by [Donor Name]", donor plaque at the vehicle storage bay, and an invitation to the inaugural estate tour by golf cart.
nodes.description: A fleet of utility terrain vehicles (UTVs) and electric golf carts forming the operational backbone of estate logistics - used for forest dining delivery, trail maintenance and grooming, guest transport, emergency access, animal care supply runs, and staff circulation across 300-400 acres. The $55,000 covers an initial fleet of 4-6 vehicles: two heavy-duty UTVs for maintenance and trail work, two electric golf carts for guest-facing transport and light logistics, and one ATV for tighter trail sections. Monthly costs of $800 cover fuel, charging, maintenance, and servicing. Without this fleet, forest dining cannot operate (golf cart delivery is specified in its description), ski trail grooming is impossible, and the scale of the estate makes foot-only staff circulation impractical. The fleet expands in later phases as villa count and operational complexity grow.

nodes.label: Broadband Infrastructure
nodes.perk: Infrastructure naming: "Broadband Infrastructure made possible by [Donor Name]", donor plaque at the network hub, and acknowledgment on the estate's infrastructure transparency page.
nodes.potentialGrantRevenue: USDA ReConnect rural broadband grants and Maine ConnectME Authority funding. Estimated $15,000-$38,000 one-time grant potential.
nodes.description: Reliable high-speed internet connectivity across the estate - a capital infrastructure project in rural Maine where connectivity cannot be assumed. The $38,000 covers site survey and ISP negotiation, installation of a fixed wireless or fiber connection at the estate boundary, a central distribution node at the founder home, and a mesh network extending to key operational areas: the sanctuary, veterinary facility, parking lot, and primary staff areas. Villa connectivity is handled as a separate fitout item within each villa build. Monthly costs of $600 cover the primary service contract and network maintenance. Reliable broadband is a prerequisite for the RFID system backend, the online Kustom Kibble reorder platform, the villa booking system, veterinary diagnostic equipment, the youth program's educational connectivity commitment, and basic staff operations. In rural Southern Maine, this requires deliberate infrastructure investment rather than a utility signup.

nodes.label: Wastewater & Septic Scaling
nodes.perk: Infrastructure naming: "Wastewater Infrastructure made possible by [Donor Name]", acknowledgment on the estate's infrastructure transparency page.
nodes.description: Engineered wastewater management infrastructure scaled for Phase 2-3 operational loads - moving beyond the founder home's conventional septic to a system handling the central village, sanitation block, and first villa cluster simultaneously. The $185,000 covers a licensed site evaluation and engineered septic design, installation of a primary treatment system sized for 30-50 villa equivalents with expansion capacity, leach field engineering appropriate for Maine soil and frost conditions, and the distribution network connecting the sanitation block and central village to the system. Maine's strict subsurface wastewater regulations and seasonal frost depth make this a serious civil engineering project. The founder home septic handles Phase 1. This node is required before the central village or any villa cluster can be occupied. The $400 monthly covers inspection, pumping cycles, and maintenance. Failure to plan this correctly is one of the most expensive mistakes a rural estate of this scale can make.

nodes.label: Cold Storage Facility
nodes.perk: Facility naming: "Cold Storage made possible by [Donor Name]", acknowledgment on the estate's operational infrastructure page.
nodes.description: A purpose-built cold storage facility serving the estate's food and beverage ecosystem - the shared refrigerated and frozen storage infrastructure that the restaurant, Dutch Snackbar, Mushroom Grove harvest, Kustom Kibble ingredient inventory, and Gingerworks all depend on. The $45,000 covers a commercial walk-in refrigeration unit (400-600 sq ft), a separate freezer section, a dry goods storage area, and the electrical and drainage fitout required for food-safe commercial storage in a Maine climate. Sited adjacent to the central village kitchen for operational efficiency. Monthly costs of $300 cover electricity and maintenance. Without centralized cold storage, each food operation requires its own refrigeration - an expensive, redundant, and maintenance-heavy arrangement at the scale New Doggerland eventually operates.

nodes.label: Rescue Duck Facility
nodes.perk: Facility naming: "Duck Sanctuary made possible by [Donor Name]", permanent plaque at the enclosure gate, and optional named individual duck sponsorships for secondary donors.
nodes.description: A purpose-built waterfowl enclosure providing permanent sanctuary for rescued ducks - the fourth species in New Doggerland's animal sanctuary alongside dogs, goats, and donkeys. The $8,500 covers a predator-proof pen with hardware cloth on all sides including the roof (minimum 6x6 ft per duck, target 10x10 ft for a flock of 6-8), a weatherproof shelter with bedded floor, a small pond or stock tank with ramp access and drainage, an automatic feeder and waterer system, and perimeter fencing. Ducks are explicitly named as a species in the animal sponsorship program and Kustom Kibble protein ingredient list - the absence of a duck facility while offering duck sponsorships would be an inconsistency. The flock provides ground-level pest and insect control across adjacent areas, produces eggs for the restaurant and snackbar, and provides quiet, low-stress animal presence complementing the goat and donkey programs. Monthly costs of $400 cover feed, veterinary care, bedding, and pond maintenance.

nodes.label: Community Foster Network
nodes.perk: Program naming: "Community Foster Network made possible by [Donor Name]", permanent acknowledgment on program materials, and the option to sponsor a dedicated foster supply kit for each new approved foster household.
nodes.potentialGrantRevenue: Animal welfare foundation grants and state companion animal program funding. Estimated $20,000-$60,000/year.
nodes.description: A formal external foster program recruiting, training, and supporting community members to temporarily house sanctuary dogs in their own homes - the primary mechanism for scaling dog throughput beyond what in-house kennel capacity allows. At 250+ dogs per year, on-site housing is never sufficient. Foster homes provide the behavioral data, real-world household testing, and human socialization that kennel environments cannot replicate, producing more accurate adoptability assessments and significantly higher adoption success rates. The $12,000 covers program development, foster family recruitment and screening protocols, a training curriculum, a foster resource library, and the initial cohort of 20-30 approved foster households. The $3,500 monthly covers a foster coordinator role (part-time initially, full-time at scale), veterinary costs for fostered dogs, emergency support, and supply provision for foster families. Foster families are never asked to fund the dog's care - food, vet, and supplies are all provided by ND. A target of 50+ active foster households within 24 months effectively doubles the sanctuary's operational capacity without a single additional kennel.

nodes.label: Dog Training Program
nodes.perk: Program naming: "Dog Training Program made possible by [Donor Name]", permanent acknowledgment on program materials, and a complimentary private training session with the head trainer for the lead sponsor.
nodes.description: A structured canine training and behavior program serving both sanctuary dogs and estate guests - the operational backbone of behavioral rehabilitation for rescue dogs and a significant revenue line for the resort. The $22,000 covers training equipment and infrastructure (agility equipment, behavior assessment tools, training yards, observation areas), initial trainer recruitment and certification alignment, and program design for both sanctuary and guest-facing components. The $7,500 monthly covers a head trainer (certified behaviorist level, $65,000-$80,000/year) and one assistant trainer, plus ongoing supplies and equipment maintenance. Sanctuary component: every dog receives a structured behavior assessment within 72 hours of intake, a tailored rehabilitation plan, and documented training progress that informs matchmaking recommendations and adoption placement. Guest component: private sessions ($120-$180/hour), group classes ($35-$50/person), a Canine Good Citizen certification program, and specialized modules including recall, reactive dog management, and puppy foundations. Guest training sessions are available to both villa guests and local community members, generating $60,000-$120,000/year in additional revenue at full capacity.

nodes.label: Dedicated Dog Wash Stations
nodes.perk: Station naming: "Dog Wash Stations made possible by [Donor Name]", permanent plaque at the wash area, and named individual stations for secondary donors.
nodes.description: Dedicated purpose-built dog wash stations serving estate guests, day visitors, and trail users returning from the estate's outdoor activities - separate from and superior to the basic wash points in the sanitation block. The $18,000 covers installation of 3-4 elevated stainless steel wash tubs at the correct working height for handlers (eliminating the back strain of ground-level washing), warm water supply with adjustable pressure, non-slip surfaces throughout, restraint bars and adjustable neck loops, built-in shampoo and conditioner dispensers stocked with estate-selected products, and a forced-air drying station with temperature control. Sited at the transition point between the trail network and the central village - the natural moment guests want to clean their dog before entering dining or retail areas. Self-use fee of $8-$12 per wash. Monthly costs of $400 cover supplies, maintenance, and water. Revenue at moderate utilization (5-8 washes/day): $14,600-$35,000/year. The wash stations are also the physical prerequisite for the grooming studio - demonstrating guest demand and establishing the water and drainage infrastructure the studio depends on.

nodes.label: Dog Grooming Studio
nodes.perk: Studio naming: "Dog Grooming Studio made possible by [Donor Name]", permanent donor plaque at the studio entrance, and a complimentary full groom for the lead sponsor's dog.
nodes.description: A full-service professional dog grooming studio occupying dedicated space in or adjacent to the central village - the estate's primary grooming operation serving villa guests, day visitors, and community members. The $95,000 covers fitout of 600-800 sq ft of grooming space: 4 professional grooming tables with hydraulic lifts, 4 elevated bathing tubs with warm water and forced-air drying integrated, a high-velocity professional dryer bay, a separate drying room with kennels for post-groom drying, a retail display for grooming products and accessories, reception desk and booking system, and all plumbing, drainage, and electrical infrastructure. The studio is staffed by 2 full-time professional groomers ($42,000-$52,000/year each) plus the grooming apprentices from the training program. Service menu ranges from a basic bath and brush ($45-$65) through full breed-standard grooms ($95-$175) to spa treatments including blueberry facials, pawdicures, and conditioning treatments ($25-$55 add-ons). At 10-20 dogs per day across the team, annual revenue is $85,000-$180,000. The studio is also the practical training facility for the grooming training program and a natural placement site for youth program participants pursuing grooming as a trade.

nodes.label: Grooming Training Program
nodes.perk: Program naming: "Grooming Training Program made possible by [Donor Name]", permanent acknowledgment on program materials, and a named apprenticeship position sponsored annually by the lead donor.
nodes.potentialGrantRevenue: Workforce development grants (WIOA), Maine Department of Labor training funds, and vocational training foundation grants. Estimated $15,000-$40,000/year.
nodes.description: A formal grooming apprenticeship and certification program using the estate's grooming studio as its training facility - a structured pathway from no experience to industry-recognized professional certification in 12-18 months. The $28,000 covers program development and curriculum design aligned with National Dog Groomers Association of America (NDGAA) certification standards, recruitment and onboarding materials, training tools and practice equipment, and the first cohort of 3-4 apprentices. Monthly costs of $3,000 cover the head groomer's additional training responsibilities and program coordination. Apprentices work paid shifts in the studio from day one - generating revenue while learning - with compensation structured to increase as they progress through certification levels. The program is explicitly connected to the Youth Out of Care Program as one of the trade pathways available to participants: grooming is a portable, in-demand, and self-employment-eligible skill that a program graduate can take anywhere. Tuition revenue from external students ($2,000-$3,500 per 6-month course) supplements the revenue from apprentice-performed services. Annual net revenue after program costs: $20,000-$45,000.

nodes.label: Estate Gift Shop & Retail
nodes.perk: Shop naming: "Estate Gift Shop made possible by [Donor Name]", permanent donor plaque at the shop entrance, and a curated gift box of estate products delivered annually to the lead sponsor.
nodes.description: A dedicated retail storefront in the central village carrying estate-produced and estate-branded goods - the physical and commercial home of everything New Doggerland makes, grows, or commissions. The $35,000 covers retail fitout: shelving, display cases, a point-of-sale system with integrated online store, lighting, and initial inventory. Product lines include Gingerworks bottled products (the flagship retail item), chaga tea and dried product, estate-grown mushrooms and preserves, artisan partner work (bootmaker, woodworker, blacksmith, herbalist), branded merchandise (apparel, leads, collars, estate-branded dog accessories), printed estate maps and art prints, and Kustom Kibble sample packs. The gift shop is also the public-facing retail channel for products purchasable without a villa stay - the mechanism by which day visitors, local community members, and online customers access estate products. Monthly costs of $4,500 cover a shop manager, part-time staff, inventory restocking, and platform fees. Annual revenue at full villa occupancy: $150,000-$400,000.

nodes.label: Weddings & Events Program
nodes.perk: Program naming: "Weddings & Events Program made possible by [Donor Name]", permanent acknowledgment on all program materials, and a complimentary estate event for the lead sponsor's use.
nodes.description: A commercial events program offering the estate as a venue for weddings, private celebrations, corporate retreats, and memorial services - one of the highest per-day revenue opportunities in New Doggerland's entire financial model. The $48,000 covers events infrastructure: a dedicated events coordinator office, a portable ceremony staging kit (arch, chairs, aisle markers in estate aesthetic), outdoor audio system, a weather contingency structure (sailcloth tent or timber-frame canopy erected for events and stored between them), and a dedicated booking and planning platform. Monthly costs of $5,500 cover the events coordinator and part-time support staff. The estate's existing assets form the venue: the chapel for ceremonies, forest dining infrastructure for receptions, the trail network for processions, the restaurant for catering, and villa clusters for guest accommodation. Dogs are welcome at all events. At 30-50 events per year averaging $8,000-$18,000 per event (intimate forest weddings command significant premiums), annual revenue is $240,000-$900,000. The UU minister provides officiant services for weddings and memorials.

nodes.label: Farmers Market
nodes.perk: Market naming: "Farmers Market made possible by [Donor Name]", permanent plaque at the market entry, and a reserved vendor stall in perpetuity for the lead sponsor or their designee.
nodes.description: A weekly or bi-weekly farmers market held on estate grounds from Phase 1, serving as a community-facing revenue and relationship-building channel for estate produce and the broader local food ecosystem. The $4,500 covers basic market infrastructure: 8-12 timber vendor stalls with weather covers built by the estate woodworker, a simple entry point with signage, and basic electrical hookups for vendors. The market is open to external local vendors alongside ND's own produce operations - mushrooms from the Mushroom Grove, firewood, chaga products, ginger, food forest harvest, eggs from the duck flock, and surplus from the restaurant kitchen. External vendors pay a modest pitch fee ($15-$25) that partially offsets operational costs. The market generates $20,000-$45,000/year in produce sales and pitch fees, creates a weekly reason for the local community to visit the property before the resort is operational, and builds the goodwill and political relationships that a new rural institution needs from Phase 1. Monthly costs of $600 cover a market coordinator stipend and vendor management.

nodes.label: Estate Membership Program
nodes.perk: Program naming: "Estate Membership Program made possible by [Donor Name]", permanent acknowledgment on program materials, and a Steward tier membership in perpetuity for the lead sponsor.
nodes.description: An annual membership program providing local and regional supporters with regular access to estate amenities, priority booking, and community belonging at an accessible price point. The $8,000 covers membership platform development (online portal, digital membership cards, booking integration), design and production of physical welcome packs, and initial marketing. Three tiers: Community ($150/year - trail access, farmers market discount, one day guest pass), Friend ($350/year - all Community benefits plus priority booking for bookable amenities, unlimited dog park access, one forest dining session), and Steward ($750/year - all Friend benefits plus one free villa night, Long Table invitation, annual estate update from the Founder Steward). Monthly costs of $1,200 cover platform maintenance and membership coordination. At 200 Community, 100 Friend, and 30 Steward members, annual recurring revenue is approximately $97,500 before any utilization of included benefits. The program is also the estate's primary donor pipeline: members who feel genuine belonging are significantly more likely to make major gifts than cold-approached prospects.

nodes.label: Estate Bakery
nodes.perk: Bakery naming: "Estate Bakery made possible by [Donor Name]", permanent donor plaque at the bakery counter, and a weekly bread delivery to the lead sponsor for one year.
nodes.description: A small production bakery integrated into the central village kitchen, producing bread, pastries, and baked goods for the restaurant, Long Table dinners, forest dining delivery, and retail sale through the gift shop and farmers market. The $42,000 covers a professional deck oven, proofing cabinet, commercial mixer, marble work surfaces, bread storage and cooling infrastructure, and fitout of the bakery station within the central village kitchen. The head baker - referenced in the Long Table description as a core member of the estate's food production team - is a salaried position ($48,000-$58,000/year) covered in the monthly costs of $6,500 alongside ingredients and packaging. Products include estate-grain sourdough using locally milled flour, seasonal pastries using food forest fruits and herbs,, and dog-safe baked treats sold through Kustom Kibble and the gift shop. The bakery produces the one product that most reliably makes a physical space smell welcoming. Annual revenue from retail and wholesale supply to the restaurant: $55,000-$120,000.

nodes.label: Free Library & Gear Share
nodes.perk: Cabinet naming: "Free Library made possible by [Donor Name]", small carved plaque on the cabinet exterior.
nodes.description: A small free library and used dog gear exchange housed in a purpose-built weatherproof cabinet at the public dog park or central village entry - take a book, leave a book; take a lead, leave a lead. The $3,500 covers construction of a double-sided cabinet by the estate woodworker (one side books, one side dog gear), installation, and initial stock. The dog gear side accepts and redistributes donated leads, harnesses, crates, travel bowls, coats, and training tools - gear that families outgrow, upgrade, or no longer need, redirected to adopters, foster families, and community members who need it. Monthly costs of $100 cover restocking and maintenance. Cost is negligible; value is disproportionate. For a new rural institution trying to earn genuine local affection rather than toleration, a free library at the dog park signals more clearly than any press release that this place is for the community, not just for wealthy visitors.

nodes.label: Artisan Partnership Program
nodes.perk: Program naming: "Artisan Partnership Program made possible by [Donor Name]", permanent acknowledgment on program materials and the estate website's artisan pages, and an invitation to the inaugural artisan welcome gathering.
nodes.potentialGrantRevenue: Maine Arts Commission grants and craft preservation funding. Estimated $10,000-$30,000/year.
nodes.description: The formal program structure governing how New Doggerland recruits, contracts, and supports its resident artisan partners - the blacksmith, bootmaker, baker, woodworker, herbalist, and others whose craft is embedded in the estate's identity and operations. The $18,000 covers program development: legal drafting of the artisan partnership agreement template (separate from employment contracts - these are craft partnerships with specific autonomy, commission, and residency provisions), recruitment materials and outreach to craft communities, workshop space fitout for the first 2-3 artisans operating before artisan housing is complete, and the first year of program coordination. Monthly costs of $2,000 cover the program coordinator (part-time) and artisan support costs. The program establishes the terms under which artisans operate: creative autonomy within their craft, commission structure for goods sold through the gift shop and direct, access to estate materials and infrastructure, pathway to artisan housing, and the expectation of participation in the estate's educational and apprenticeship programs. Without this program node, the artisan housing node has no pipeline and no governance framework. The Repair Culture workshop is the artisans' shared workspace.

nodes.label: Agricultural College Partnership
nodes.perk: Partnership naming: "Agricultural College Partnership made possible by [Donor Name]", acknowledgment on partnership materials and the estate website.
nodes.potentialGrantRevenue: USDA agricultural education grants, Maine Department of Agriculture cooperative funding. Estimated $15,000-$40,000/year.
nodes.description: A formal memorandum of understanding with the University of Maine system or equivalent Maine agricultural college, establishing New Doggerland as an approved placement and research partner for students in animal science, sustainable agriculture, forestry, veterinary technology, and related programs. The $5,000 covers legal review of the MOU, initial partnership development costs, and the first year of placement coordination. Monthly costs of $500 cover ongoing placement administration and the liaison relationship with the institution. The partnership provides New Doggerland with a structured pipeline of skilled student placements across the goat and donkey programs, food forest, repair workshop, sanctuary, and veterinary facility - reducing staffing costs and building relationships with future employees. In exchange, the college gains an unusually well-resourced and mission-aligned placement site. The partnership also enhances grant eligibility across multiple funding categories and provides access to agricultural research expertise relevant to the estate's land management challenges.

nodes.label: Volunteer Program
nodes.perk: Program naming: "Volunteer Program made possible by [Donor Name]", acknowledgment on program materials, and named recognition on the estate's founding volunteer wall in the central village.
nodes.description: A formal volunteer program managing the recruitment, training, scheduling, welfare, and recognition of the volunteers who contribute meaningfully to New Doggerland's operations from Phase 1 onward. Volunteers appear in nearly every operational domain: trail building, BMX and disc golf course construction, sanctuary dog socialization and walking, farmers market operation, foster network support, and community events. Without a formal program, volunteer involvement is ad-hoc, inconsistent, and potentially a liability. The $9,000 covers program design and legal review (volunteer waiver and liability framework for a site involving dogs, trails, and heavy machinery), a volunteer management platform, onboarding and orientation materials, and basic uniform and identification items. Monthly costs of $1,500 cover a volunteer coordinator role (part-time, growing to full-time in Phase 3) and recognition events. A well-run volunteer program at this scale - targeting 200+ active volunteers by Phase 2 - contributes the equivalent of 3-5 full-time positions in labor value while building a deeply invested local community who become donors, ambassadors, and long-term supporters.

nodes.label: Sauna & Cold Plunge
nodes.perk: Facility naming: "Sauna & Cold Plunge made possible by [Donor Name]", permanent donor plaque at the entrance, and a standing complimentary session for the lead sponsor on each estate visit.
nodes.description: A Nordic-tradition sauna and cold plunge facility sited in the forest, designed as a year-round wellness destination with particular appeal in Maine's winter months. The $85,000 covers a wood-fired traditional Finnish sauna structure (8-10 person capacity, timber construction consistent with estate aesthetic), a cold plunge pool fed by the estate's water system and cooled naturally in winter, a changing area with bench seating and hooks, and a covered outdoor rest deck with Adirondack chairs overlooking the forest. Sited within easy walking distance of the villa cluster but set into the trees for privacy and atmosphere. Bookable in 90-minute sessions at $35-$55 per person, with private booking for groups at $150-$250 per session. At 4-6 sessions per day during peak season and 2-3 during quieter periods, annual revenue is $40,000-$90,000. Monthly costs of $1,800 cover firewood supply, water system maintenance, linen service, and cleaning. Dogs are permitted in the outdoor rest area and approach path. The sauna and cold plunge is the single most requested amenity type missing from the current estate program among the premium forest resort demographic.

nodes.label: Night Sky & Stargazing Program
nodes.perk: Program naming: "Night Sky Program made possible by [Donor Name]", permanent acknowledgment on program materials, and an invitation to the inaugural first-light viewing session.
nodes.description: A structured night sky and stargazing program exploiting one of New Doggerland's most underutilized natural assets: Southern Maine's genuinely dark skies, far enough from major light pollution to offer clear views on favorable nights. The $12,000 covers a cleared and leveled primary viewing area (a forest opening with an unobstructed sky arc), 8-10 reclining Adirondack chairs with blanket storage boxes, a warming station with chaga tea and hot drinks, two quality refracting telescopes on stable mounts, a red-light-only lighting system that preserves night vision on the approach path, and interpretive materials (printed star charts, seasonal sky guides).
