Guided sessions are offered at $35-$55 per person on clear nights, bookable in advance via the estate system, with a minimum of 4 guests per session. Self-guided access is included for villa guests. Dogs on lead are welcome at all sessions. Monthly costs of $400 cover equipment maintenance, consumables, and guide stipends. Revenue is weather-dependent but Southern Maine averages 160+ clear nights per year - sufficient for a reliable seasonal offering.

nodes.label: Named Inaugural Use
nodes.description: A formal program ensuring that every significant node in the New Doggerland development plan has a defined Inaugural Use moment - the first time the thing that was funded is used by a human being, reserved by right for the donor who funded it. This is categorically different from naming rights. A plaque is passive. Inaugural use is a lived, unrepeatable experience: the first meal served at the Long Table, the first night in the first villa, the first dog groomed in the grooming studio, the first family on the off-leash trail, the first fire lit in the Unitarian Chapel. These moments exist once. They cannot be purchased after the fact. The $8,000 covers program design and documentation (defining the inaugural moment for each applicable node, the invitation protocol, the ceremony if any, and the record-keeping), coordination of scheduling and logistics with donors, and production of a commemorative item for each inaugural use (a hand-printed card, a photograph, a letter from the Founder Steward - something physical that the donor keeps). Monthly costs of $500 cover the program coordinator's time as nodes activate across phases. The inaugural use framing should be written into funding instruments at the time of gift, not offered retroactively. It is part of what the donor is buying when they fund a node - not a thank-you add-on, but a structural element of the giving experience.

nodes.label: Build Visit Program
nodes.description: A structured program offering major donors the opportunity to visit the estate during construction phases and witness or participate in the building of what they funded. Not a hard-hat tour with a PR handler. A real visit, on the site, with the people doing the work. The drystone waller explaining the coursing logic of the perimeter wall while a donor places a stone in the section their gift funded. The food forest planting weekend where donors join staff putting heritage apple trees in the ground. The day the first rescue dogs arrive at the completed sanctuary, with the founding donors present in the courtyard. The $5,000 covers program design, safety protocols for construction site visits, logistics documentation, and the first year of coordination. Monthly costs of $800 cover scheduling, communications, and on-site hospitality for visits (simple - food from the snackbar, the founder's kitchen, whatever is operational at the time). Build visits are available to donors above a defined threshold (suggested: $25,000+ cumulative commitment). They are never mandatory and never performative - donors are invited into the actual working environment, not a staged version of it. A donor who watches the master waller explain why the wall will still stand in 200 years has a fundamentally different relationship to the organization than one who receives an annual report. Build visits create that relationship at the moment when the physical thing being funded is most tangible and most alive.

nodes.label: Witnessing Moments Program
nodes.description: A carefully designed program that closes the loop between infrastructure donors and the living outcomes their gifts produced - in ways that protect privacy, avoid charity theater, and create genuine correspondence rather than marketing. Two tracks operate in parallel. The sanctuary track: donors who funded the veterinary facility, transport fleet, community foster network, or sanctuary infrastructure periodically receive a photograph, a name, and a brief note about a dog who passed through the system their gift built. Not a form letter. A real account of a specific animal - where it came from, what it needed, where it landed. Sent by the sanctuary coordinator, not the development office. Consent and privacy for adopting families is managed through an opt-in at adoption. The youth program track: donors who funded the Youth Out of Care Program, Youth Program Space, or Youth Program Dogs can receive (with explicit participant consent and full anonymization unless the participant chooses otherwise) occasional correspondence about how the program is functioning - a participant who found employment in their trained trade, a dog placement that worked, a family formed. This is not the participant on display for the donor. It is the donor receiving evidence that the system they funded is doing what it was built to do. The $6,000 covers program design, consent framework development, legal review of privacy protocols, and staff training. Monthly costs of $1,200 cover coordination time across sanctuary and youth program staff. The program deliberately produces no content for public use - these communications are private, between the organization and individual donors.

nodes.label: Donor Stay Program
nodes.description: A structured annual stay program for major donors, built into funding instruments at the time of gift rather than offered retroactively as a thank-you. Villa donors receive a standing annual invitation to stay in the villa they funded - or the nearest equivalent if their specific villa is occupied - for a defined period each year (typically 3-5 nights). Major donors above a threshold who funded infrastructure, sanctuary, or program nodes rather than specific villas receive an equivalent annual stay invitation at the estate's expense. The program is not a discount or a priority booking. It is a dedicated allocation - these nights are reserved in the estate calendar and held until 60 days before the visit window, at which point they return to general inventory if unused. The $12,000 covers program design, integration with the villa booking system, legal drafting of the stay entitlement language for inclusion in funding instruments, and the first year of coordination. Monthly costs of $2,000 cover the program coordinator role and the operational cost of donor stays (food, housekeeping, incidentals - the villa itself carries no marginal cost beyond operations). The strategic logic is straightforward: a donor who returns to the estate every year for a decade sees what has grown. They walk trails they helped build. They eat in a restaurant their gift made possible. They meet a dog that the sanctuary rescued. They are not funders of an abstraction - they are stakeholders in a place. That relationship produces renewal, increased gifts, peer recruitment, and estate gifts. The annual stay is not a cost. It is the highest-return investment the organization makes in donor relationships.

nodes.label: Founders' Gathering
nodes.description: An annual invitation-only weekend at the estate for the donors and founding members who built Phase 1 and Phase 2 of New Doggerland - the people without whom the place would not exist. Not a gala. Not a cultivation dinner in a hotel ballroom. Not a thank-you event with speeches and slideshows. A weekend at the estate itself: in the villas, eating from the kitchen they funded, walking the trails they built, sitting around a fire, meeting the dogs that moved through the sanctuary their gifts made operational. The Long Table format - everyone present at the same table, no hierarchy, no assigned seating by gift size, no donor recognition segment, no ask. Just the place and the people who built it together. The $18,000 covers the first gathering: food and beverage production for 30-50 guests across the weekend, villa allocation (founding donors stay at no charge during the gathering), activity coordination, and the logistics of bringing people from across the country to rural Maine. Monthly costs of $3,500 represent the annualized planning and coordination budget across the year between gatherings. The gathering happens once per year, typically in late September when the Maine foliage is at its peak and the summer operational pressure has eased. Attendance is by invitation only and limited to donors who have been part of the build from Phase 1 or 2. As the estate grows, a separate gathering for Phase 3 and 4 donors may be established - but the founding gathering remains small, intentional, and exclusive to those who were present at the beginning. The gathering has no formal agenda. No one is asked for anything. Major gifts will be contemplated anyway - because belonging generates generosity, and because people who have spent a weekend watching the thing they built working in the forest understand exactly what another gift would do.

oneTimes.description: Commercial-grade snow blower for winter trail and access maintenance. Capable of cutting cross-country ski tracks.

oneTimes.description: Hydraulic log splitter for firewood program and land clearing operations.

oneTimes.description: Professional-grade chainsaw with safety gear for trail maintenance and forestry work.
